Listing 9-2: Backtrace ƒë∆∞·ª£c t·∫°o ra b·ªüi m·ªôt cu·ªôc g·ªçi panic! ƒë∆∞·ª£c hi·ªÉn th·ªã khi bi·∫øn m√¥i tr∆∞·ªùng RUST_BACKTRACE ƒë∆∞·ª£c thi·∫øt l·∫≠p

Nhi·ªÅu ouput ƒë∆∞·ª£c in ra! Ouput c·ª• th·ªÉ b·∫°n th·∫•y c√≥ th·ªÉ kh√°c nhau t√πy thu·ªôc v√†o h·ªá ƒëi·ªÅu h√†nh v√† phi√™n b·∫£n Rust c·ªßa b·∫°n. ƒê·ªÉ c√≥ ƒë∆∞·ª£c backtraces v·ªõi th√¥ng tin n√†y, c√°c k√Ω hi·ªáu g·ª° l·ªói ph·∫£i ƒë∆∞·ª£c b·∫≠t. K√Ω hi·ªáu g·ª° l·ªói ƒë∆∞·ª£c b·∫≠t m·∫∑c ƒë·ªãnh khi s·ª≠ d·ª•ng cargo build ho·∫∑c cargo run m√† kh√¥ng c√≥ c·ªù --release, nh∆∞ ch√∫ng t√¥i ƒë√£ c√≥ ·ªü ƒë√¢y.

Trong ouput trong Listing 9-2, d√≤ng 6 c·ªßa backtrace ch·ªâ ƒë·∫øn d√≤ng trong d·ª± √°n c·ªßa ch√∫ng ta g√¢y ra v·∫•n ƒë·ªÅ: d√≤ng 4 c·ªßa src/main.rs. N·∫øu ch√∫ng ta kh√¥ng mu·ªën ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh c·ªßa ch√∫ng ta b·ªã panic, ch√∫ng ta n√™n b·∫Øt ƒë·∫ßu ƒëi·ªÅu tra t·∫°i v·ªã tr√≠ ƒë∆∞·ª£c ch·ªâ ƒë·∫øn b·ªüi d√≤ng ƒë·∫ßu ti√™n n√≥i v·ªÅ m·ªôt t·ªáp m√† ch√∫ng ta ƒë√£ vi·∫øt. Trong Listing 9-1, khi ch√∫ng ta c√≥ √Ω ƒë·ªãnh vi·∫øt m√£ s·∫Ω b·ªã panic, c√°ch ƒë·ªÉ s·ª≠a l·ªói panic l√† kh√¥ng y√™u c·∫ßu m·ªôt ph·∫ßn t·ª≠ ngo√†i ph·∫°m vi c·ªßa c√°c ch·ªâ s·ªë vector. Khi m√£ c·ªßa b·∫°n b·ªã panic trong t∆∞∆°ng lai, b·∫°n s·∫Ω c·∫ßn ph·∫£i suy nghƒ© v·ªÅ h√†nh ƒë·ªông m√£ ƒëang th·ª±c hi·ªán v·ªõi gi√° tr·ªã n√†o ƒë·ªÉ g√¢y ra panic v√† m√£ n√™n l√†m g√¨ thay th·∫ø.

Ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω quay l·∫°i panic! v√† khi n√†o ch√∫ng ta n√™n v√† kh√¥ng n√™n s·ª≠ d·ª•ng panic! ƒë·ªÉ x·ª≠ l√Ω c√°c ƒëi·ªÅu ki·ªán l·ªói trong ph·∫ßn ‚ÄúTo panic! or Not to panic!‚Äù sau trong ch∆∞∆°ng n√†y. Ti·∫øp theo, ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω xem c√°ch kh√¥i ph·ª•c l·ªói b·∫±ng c√°ch s·ª≠ d·ª•ng Result.

Recoverable Errors with Result

H·∫ßu h·∫øt c√°c l·ªói kh√¥ng ƒë·ªß nghi√™m tr·ªçng ƒë·ªÉ y√™u c·∫ßu ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh d·ª´ng ho√†n to√†n. ƒê√¥i khi, khi m·ªôt h√†m th·∫•t b·∫°i, n√≥ l√† v√¨ m·ªôt l√Ω do m√† b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ d·ªÖ d√†ng di·ªÖn gi·∫£i v√† ph·∫£n ·ª©ng. V√≠ d·ª•, n·∫øu b·∫°n c·ªë g·∫Øng m·ªü m·ªôt t·ªáp v√† ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông th·∫•t b·∫°i b·ªüi v√¨ t·ªáp kh√¥ng t·ªìn t·∫°i, b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ mu·ªën t·∫°o t·ªáp thay v√¨ k·∫øt th√∫c qu√° tr√¨nh.

Nh·∫Øc l·∫°i t·ª´ ‚ÄúHandling Potential Failure with the Result Type‚Äù trong Ch∆∞∆°ng 2 r·∫±ng Result enum ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a l√† c√≥ hai bi·∫øn th·ªÉ, Ok v√† Err, nh∆∞ sau:

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
enum Result<T, E> {
    Ok(T),
    Err(E),
}
}

T v√† E l√† c√°c tham s·ªë ki·ªÉu generic: ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω th·∫£o lu·∫≠n v·ªÅ generic k·ªπ h∆°n trong Ch∆∞∆°ng 10. B·∫°n c·∫ßn bi·∫øt ngay b√¢y gi·ªù l√† T bi·ªÉu di·ªÖn ki·ªÉu c·ªßa gi√° tr·ªã s·∫Ω ƒë∆∞·ª£c tr·∫£ v·ªÅ trong tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p th√†nh c√¥ng trong bi·∫øn th·ªÉ Ok, v√† E bi·ªÉu di·ªÖn ki·ªÉu c·ªßa l·ªói s·∫Ω ƒë∆∞·ª£c tr·∫£ v·ªÅ trong tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p th·∫•t b·∫°i trong bi·∫øn th·ªÉ Err. B·ªüi v√¨ Result c√≥ c√°c tham s·ªë ki·ªÉu generic n√†y, ch√∫ng ta c√≥ th·ªÉ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng ki·ªÉu Result v√† c√°c h√†m ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a tr√™n n√≥ trong nhi·ªÅu t√¨nh hu·ªëng kh√°c nhau m√† gi√° tr·ªã th√†nh c√¥ng v√† gi√° tr·ªã l·ªói m√† ch√∫ng ta mu·ªën tr·∫£ v·ªÅ c√≥ th·ªÉ kh√°c nhau.

C√πng g·ªçi m·ªôt h√†m m√† tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Result b·ªüi v√¨ h√†m c√≥ th·ªÉ th·∫•t b·∫°i. Trong Listing 9-3 ch√∫ng ta c·ªë g·∫Øng m·ªü m·ªôt t·ªáp.

Filename: src/main.rs

use std::fs::File;

fn main() {
    let greeting_file_result = File::open("hello.txt");
}

Listing 9-3: M·ªü m·ªôt t·ªáp

Ki·ªÉu tr·∫£ v·ªÅ c·ªßa File::open l√† Result<T, E>. Tham s·ªë ki·ªÉu generic T ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒëi·ªÅn v√†o b·ªüi hi·ªán th·ª±c File::open v·ªõi ki·ªÉu c·ªßa gi√° tr·ªã khi g·ªçi th√†nh c√¥ng l√† std::fs::File, ƒë√≥ l√† m·ªôt file handle. Ki·ªÉu c·ªßa E ƒë∆∞·ª£c s·ª≠ d·ª•ng trong gi√° v√† gi√° tr·ªã l·ªói l√† std::io::Error. Ki·ªÉu tr·∫£ v·ªÅ n√†y c√≥ nghƒ©a l√† l·ªùi g·ªçi ƒë·∫øn File::open c√≥ th·ªÉ th√†nh c√¥ng v√† tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt file handle m√† ch√∫ng ta c√≥ th·ªÉ ƒë·ªçc ho·∫∑c ghi. L·ªùi g·ªçi h√†m c≈©ng c√≥ th·ªÉ th·∫•t b·∫°i: v√≠ d·ª•, t·ªáp c√≥ th·ªÉ kh√¥ng t·ªìn t·∫°i, ho·∫∑c ch√∫ng ta c√≥ th·ªÉ kh√¥ng c√≥ quy·ªÅn truy c·∫≠p t·ªáp. H√†m File::open c·∫ßn ph·∫£i c√≥ m·ªôt c√°ch ƒë·ªÉ cho ch√∫ng ta bi·∫øt n√≥ ƒë√£ th√†nh c√¥ng hay th·∫•t b·∫°i v√† c√πng l√∫c cho ch√∫ng ta m·ªôt file handle ho·∫∑c th√¥ng tin v·ªÅ l·ªói. Th√¥ng tin n√†y ch√≠nh l√† nh·ªØng g√¨ enum Result truy·ªÅn t·∫£i.

Trong tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p File::open th√†nh c√¥ng, gi√° tr·ªã trong bi·∫øn greeting_file_result s·∫Ω l√† m·ªôt th·ªÉ hi·ªán c·ªßa Ok ch·ª©a m·ªôt file handle. Trong tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p n√≥ th·∫•t b·∫°i, gi√° tr·ªã trong greeting_file_result s·∫Ω l√† m·ªôt th·ªÉ hi·ªán c·ªßa Err ch·ª©a th√™m th√¥ng tin v·ªÅ lo·∫°i l·ªói ƒë√£ x·∫£y ra.

Ch√∫ng ta c·∫ßn th√™m v√†o code trong Listing 9-3 ƒë·ªÉ th·ª±c hi·ªán c√°c h√†nh ƒë·ªông kh√°c nhau t√πy thu·ªôc v√†o gi√° tr·ªã m√† File::open tr·∫£ v·ªÅ. Listing 9-4 cho th·∫•y m·ªôt c√°ch ƒë·ªÉ x·ª≠ l√Ω Result s·ª≠ d·ª•ng m·ªôt c√¥ng c·ª• c∆° b·∫£n, bi·ªÉu th·ª©c match m√† ch√∫ng ta ƒë√£ th·∫£o lu·∫≠n trong Ch∆∞∆°ng 6.

Filename: src/main.rs

use std::fs::File;

fn main() {
    let greeting_file_result = File::open("hello.txt");

    let greeting_file = match greeting_file_result {
        Ok(file) => file,
        Err(error) => panic!("Problem opening the file: {:?}", error),
    };
}

Listing 9-4: S·ª≠ d·ª•ng bi·ªÉu th·ª©c match ƒë·ªÉ x·ª≠ l√Ω c√°c th·ªÉ hi·ªán Result c√≥ th·ªÉ ƒë∆∞·ª£c tr·∫£ v·ªÅ

Ch√∫ √Ω r·∫±ng, gi·ªëng nh∆∞ enum Option, enum Result v√† c√°c bi·∫øn th·ªÉ c·ªßa n√≥ ƒë√£ ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë∆∞a v√†o scope b·ªüi prelude, v√¨ v·∫≠y ch√∫ng ta kh√¥ng c·∫ßn ch·ªâ ƒë·ªãnh Result:: tr∆∞·ªõc c√°c bi·∫øn th·ªÉ Ok v√† Err trong c√°c nh√°nh c·ªßa match.

Khi k·∫øt qu·∫£ l√† Ok, code n√†y s·∫Ω tr·∫£ v·ªÅ gi√° tr·ªã n·ªôi b·ªô file b√™n trong bi·∫øn th·ªÉ Ok, v√† ch√∫ng ta sau ƒë√≥ g√°n gi√° tr·ªã file handle ƒë√≥ cho bi·∫øn greeting_file. Sau match, ch√∫ng ta c√≥ th·ªÉ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng file handle ƒë·ªÉ ƒë·ªçc ho·∫∑c ghi.

Nh√°nh c√≤n l·∫°i c·ªßa match x·ª≠ l√Ω tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p ch√∫ng ta nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Err t·ª´ File::open. Trong v√≠ d·ª• n√†y, ch√∫ng ta ƒë√£ ch·ªçn g·ªçi macro panic!. N·∫øu kh√¥ng c√≥ t·ªáp n√†o c√≥ t√™n hello.txt trong th∆∞ m·ª•c hi·ªán t·∫°i c·ªßa ch√∫ng ta v√† ch√∫ng ta ch·∫°y m√£ n√†y, ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω th·∫•y ƒë·∫ßu ra sau t·ª´ macro panic!:

$ cargo run
   Compiling error-handling v0.1.0 (file:///projects/error-handling)
    Finished dev [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.73s
     Running `target/debug/error-handling`

note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace

Nh∆∞ th∆∞·ªùng l·ªá, output n√†y cho ch√∫ng ta bi·∫øt ch√≠nh x√°c l·ªói l√† g√¨.

Matching on Different Errors

Code trong Listing 9-4 s·∫Ω panic! b·∫•t k·ªÉ l√Ω do n√†o m√† File::open th·∫•t b·∫°i. Tuy nhi√™n, ch√∫ng ta mu·ªën th·ª±c hi·ªán c√°c h√†nh ƒë·ªông kh√°c nhau cho c√°c l√Ω do th·∫•t b·∫°i kh√°c nhau: n·∫øu File::open th·∫•t b·∫°i v√¨ t·ªáp kh√¥ng t·ªìn t·∫°i, ch√∫ng ta mu·ªën t·∫°o t·ªáp v√† tr·∫£ v·ªÅ handle ƒë·∫øn t·ªáp m·ªõi. N·∫øu File::open th·∫•t b·∫°i v√¨ b·∫•t k·ª≥ l√Ω do n√†o kh√°c - v√≠ d·ª•, v√¨ ch√∫ng ta kh√¥ng c√≥ quy·ªÅn m·ªü t·ªáp - ch√∫ng ta v·∫´n mu·ªën m√£ panic! theo c√°ch gi·ªëng nh∆∞ trong Listing 9-4. ƒê·ªÉ l√†m ƒëi·ªÅu n√†y, ch√∫ng ta th√™m m·ªôt bi·ªÉu th·ª©c match b√™n trong, ƒë∆∞·ª£c hi·ªÉn th·ªã trong Listing 9-5.

Filename: src/main.rs

use std::fs::File;
use std::io::ErrorKind;

fn main() {
    let greeting_file_result = File::open("hello.txt");

    let greeting_file = match greeting_file_result {
        Ok(file) => file,
        Err(error) => match error.kind() {
            ErrorKind::NotFound => match File::create("hello.txt") {
                Ok(fc) => fc,
                Err(e) => panic!("Problem creating the file: {:?}", e),
            },
            other_error => {
                panic!("Problem opening the file: {:?}", other_error);
            }
        },
    };
}

Listing 9-5: X·ª≠ l√Ω c√°c lo·∫°i l·ªói kh√°c nhau theo c√°c c√°ch kh√°c nhau

Ki·ªÉu c·ªßa gi√° tr·ªã m√† File::open tr·∫£ v·ªÅ b√™n trong bi·∫øn Err l√† io::Error, m·ªôt struct ƒë∆∞·ª£c cung c·∫•p b·ªüi th∆∞ vi·ªán chu·∫©n. Struct n√†y c√≥ m·ªôt ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c kind m√† ch√∫ng ta c√≥ th·ªÉ g·ªçi ƒë·ªÉ l·∫•y m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã io::ErrorKind. Enum io::ErrorKind ƒë∆∞·ª£c cung c·∫•p b·ªüi th∆∞ vi·ªán chu·∫©n v√† c√≥ c√°c bi·∫øn th·ªÉ bi·ªÉu th·ªã c√°c lo·∫°i l·ªói kh√°c nhau c√≥ th·ªÉ x·∫£y ra t·ª´ m·ªôt ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông io. Bi·∫øn th·ªÉ m√† ch√∫ng ta mu·ªën s·ª≠ d·ª•ng l√† ErrorKind::NotFound, bi·ªÉu th·ªã t·ªáp m√† ch√∫ng ta ƒëang c·ªë g·∫Øng m·ªü kh√¥ng t·ªìn t·∫°i. Do ƒë√≥, ch√∫ng ta match tr√™n greeting_file_result, nh∆∞ng ch√∫ng ta c≈©ng c√≥ m·ªôt match b√™n trong tr√™n error.kind().

ƒêi·ªÅu ki·ªán m√† ch√∫ng ta mu·ªën ki·ªÉm tra trong match b√™n trong l√† li·ªáu gi√° tr·ªã tr·∫£ v·ªÅ b·ªüi error.kind() c√≥ ph·∫£i l√† bi·∫øn th·ªÉ NotFound c·ªßa enum ErrorKind. N·∫øu c√≥, ch√∫ng ta c·ªë g·∫Øng t·∫°o t·ªáp v·ªõi File::create. Tuy nhi√™n, v√¨ File::create c≈©ng c√≥ th·ªÉ th·∫•t b·∫°i, ch√∫ng ta c·∫ßn m·ªôt bi·∫øn th·ªÉ th·ª© hai trong bi·ªÉu th·ª©c match b√™n trong. Khi t·ªáp kh√¥ng th·ªÉ ƒë∆∞·ª£c t·∫°o, m·ªôt th√¥ng b√°o l·ªói kh√°c ƒë∆∞·ª£c in ra. Bi·∫øn th·ªÉ th·ª© hai c·ªßa match b√™n ngo√†i v·∫´n gi·ªØ nguy√™n, v√¨ v·∫≠y ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh s·∫Ω b·ªã panic v·ªõi b·∫•t k·ª≥ l·ªói n√†o ngo√†i l·ªói t·ªáp thi·∫øu.

Alternatives to Using match with Result<T, E>

C√≥ qu√° nhi·ªÅu match! Bi·ªÉu th·ª©c match r·∫•t h·ªØu √≠ch nh∆∞ng v·∫´n l√† m·ªôt bi·ªÉu th·ª©c c∆° b·∫£n. Trong Ch∆∞∆°ng 13, b·∫°n s·∫Ω t√¨m hi·ªÉu v·ªÅ closures, ƒë∆∞·ª£c s·ª≠ d·ª•ng v·ªõi nhi·ªÅu ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a tr√™n Result<T, E>. Nh·ªØng ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c n√†y c√≥ th·ªÉ ng·∫Øn g·ªçn h∆°n so v·ªõi vi·ªác s·ª≠ d·ª•ng match khi x·ª≠ l√Ω gi√° tr·ªã Result<T, E> trong code c·ªßa b·∫°n

V√≠ d·ª•, ƒë√¢y l√† m·ªôt c√°ch kh√°c ƒë·ªÉ vi·∫øt c√πng m·ªôt logic nh∆∞ trong Listing 9-5, l·∫ßn n√†y s·ª≠ d·ª•ng closures v√† ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c unwrap_or_else:

use std::fs::File;
use std::io::ErrorKind;

fn main() {
    let greeting_file = File::open("hello.txt").unwrap_or_else(|error| {
        if error.kind() == ErrorKind::NotFound {
            File::create("hello.txt").unwrap_or_else(|error| {
                panic!("Problem creating the file: {:?}", error);
            })
        } else {
            panic!("Problem opening the file: {:?}", error);
        }
    });
}

M·∫∑c d√π code n√†y c√≥ c√πng h√†nh vi nh∆∞ Listing 9-5, n√≥ kh√¥ng ch·ª©a b·∫•t k·ª≥ bi·ªÉu th·ª©c match n√†o v√† d·ªÖ ƒë·ªçc h∆°n. Quay l·∫°i v√≠ d·ª• n√†y sau khi b·∫°n ƒë√£ ƒë·ªçc Ch∆∞∆°ng 13, v√† t√¨m ki·∫øm ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c unwrap_or_else trong t√†i li·ªáu th∆∞ vi·ªán chu·∫©n. Nhi·ªÅu ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c kh√°c c√≥ th·ªÉ l√†m ng·∫Øn g·ªçn c√°c bi·ªÉu th·ª©c match l·ªìng nhau l·ªõn khi b·∫°n ƒëang x·ª≠ l√Ω c√°c l·ªói.

Shortcuts for Panic on Error: unwrap and expect

S·ª≠ d·ª•ng match th∆∞·ªùng t·ªët, nh∆∞ng n√≥ c√≥ th·ªÉ r·∫•t d√†i d√≤ng v√† kh√≥ hi·ªÉu. Ki·ªÉu Result<T, E> c√≥ nhi·ªÅu ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c tr·ª£ gi√∫p ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a tr√™n n√≥ ƒë·ªÉ th·ª±c hi·ªán c√°c t√°c v·ª• c·ª• th·ªÉ h∆°n. Ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c unwrap l√† m·ªôt ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c t·∫Øt ƒë∆∞·ª£c th·ª±c hi·ªán gi·ªëng nh∆∞ bi·ªÉu th·ª©c match m√† ch√∫ng ta ƒë√£ vi·∫øt trong Listing 9-4. N·∫øu gi√° tr·ªã Result l√† bi·∫øn Ok, unwrap s·∫Ω tr·∫£ v·ªÅ gi√° tr·ªã b√™n trong bi·∫øn Ok. N·∫øu Result l√† bi·∫øn Err, unwrap s·∫Ω g·ªçi macro panic! gi√∫p ch√∫ng ta. ƒê√¢y l√† m·ªôt v√≠ d·ª• v·ªÅ unwrap ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông:

Filename: src/main.rs

use std::fs::File;

fn main() {
    let greeting_file = File::open("hello.txt").unwrap();
}

N·∫øu ch√∫ng ta ch·∫°y code n√†y m√† kh√¥ng c√≥ file hello.txt, ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω th·∫•y m·ªôt th√¥ng b√°o l·ªói t·ª´ l·ªánh panic! m√† ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c unwrap g·ªçi:

thread 'main' panicked at 'called `Result::unwrap()` on an `Err` value: Error {
repr: Os { code: 2, message: "No such file or directory" } }',
src/libcore/result.rs:906:4

T∆∞∆°ng t·ª±, ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c expect cho ph√©p ch√∫ng ta ch·ªçn th√¥ng b√°o l·ªói panic!. S·ª≠ d·ª•ng expect thay v√¨ unwrap v√† cung c·∫•p c√°c th√¥ng b√°o l·ªói t·ªët c√≥ th·ªÉ truy·ªÅn ƒë·∫°t √Ω ƒë·ªãnh c·ªßa b·∫°n v√† l√†m cho vi·ªác t√¨m nguy√™n nh√¢n c·ªßa m·ªôt l·ªói d·ªÖ d√†ng h∆°n. C√∫ ph√°p c·ªßa expect nh∆∞ sau:

Filename: src/main.rs

use std::fs::File;

fn main() {
    let greeting_file = File::open("hello.txt")
        .expect("hello.txt should be included in this project");
}

Ch√∫ng ta s·ª≠ d·ª•ng expect theo c√°ch gi·ªëng nh∆∞ unwrap: ƒë·ªÉ tr·∫£ v·ªÅ file handle ho·∫∑c g·ªçi macro panic!. Th√¥ng b√°o l·ªói ƒë∆∞·ª£c s·ª≠ d·ª•ng b·ªüi expect trong l·ªánh panic! s·∫Ω l√† tham s·ªë m√† ch√∫ng ta truy·ªÅn cho expect, thay v√¨ th√¥ng b√°o l·ªói m·∫∑c ƒë·ªãnh c·ªßa panic! m√† unwrap s·ª≠ d·ª•ng. ƒê√¢y l√† c√°ch n√≥ ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông:

thread 'main' panicked at 'hello.txt should be included in this project: Error
{ repr: Os { code: 2, message: "No such file or directory" } }',
src/libcore/result.rs:906:4

Trong code ·ªü production, h·∫ßu h·∫øt Rustaceans (ng∆∞·ªùi d√πng Rust) ch·ªçn expect thay v√¨ unwrap v√† cung c·∫•p th√™m th√¥ng tin v·ªÅ t·∫°i sao c√°c ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông ƒë∆∞·ª£c mong ƒë·ª£i l√† lu√¥n th√†nh c√¥ng. ƒêi·ªÅu ƒë√≥ cho ph√©p b·∫°n c√≥ th√™m th√¥ng tin ƒë·ªÉ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng trong qu√° tr√¨nh debug n·∫øu nh∆∞ c√°c gi·∫£ ƒë·ªãnh c·ªßa b·∫°n b·ªã ch·ª©ng minh sai.

Propagating Errors

Khi m·ªôt h√†m th·ª±c thi g·ªçi m·ªôt th·ª© g√¨ ƒë√≥ c√≥ th·ªÉ g√¢y ra l·ªói, thay v√¨ x·ª≠ l√Ω l·ªói trong h√†m th·ª±c thi, b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ tr·∫£ v·ªÅ l·ªói cho code g·ªçi h√†m ƒë·ªÉ n√≥ c√≥ th·ªÉ quy·∫øt ƒë·ªãnh l√†m g√¨. ƒêi·ªÅu n√†y ƒë∆∞·ª£c g·ªçi l√† propagating (lan truy·ªÅn) l·ªói v√† cho ph√©p code g·ªçi ƒë·∫øn h√†m c√≥ th·ªÉ quy·∫øt ƒë·ªãnh x·ª≠ l√Ω l·ªói theo c√°ch n√†o m√† n√≥ th√≠ch h∆°n.

V√≠ d·ª•, Listing 9-6 cho th·∫•y m·ªôt h√†m ƒë·ªçc username t·ª´ m·ªôt file. N·∫øu file kh√¥ng t·ªìn t·∫°i ho·∫∑c kh√¥ng th·ªÉ ƒë·ªçc ƒë∆∞·ª£c, h√†m n√†y s·∫Ω tr·∫£ v·ªÅ l·ªói ƒë√≥ cho code g·ªçi h√†m.

Filename: src/main.rs

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
use std::fs::File;
use std::io::{self, Read};

fn read_username_from_file() -> Result<String, io::Error> {
    let username_file_result = File::open("hello.txt");

    let mut username_file = match username_file_result {
        Ok(file) => file,
        Err(e) => return Err(e),
    };

    let mut username = String::new();

    match username_file.read_to_string(&mut username) {
        Ok(_) => Ok(username),
        Err(e) => Err(e),
    }
}
}

Listing 9-6: M·ªôt h√†m tr·∫£ v·ªÅ l·ªói cho code g·ªçi h√†m s·ª≠ d·ª•ng match

H√†m n√†y c√≥ th·ªÉ ƒë∆∞·ª£c vi·∫øt ng·∫Øn g·ªçn h∆°n, nh∆∞ng ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω b·∫Øt ƒë·∫ßu b·∫±ng c√°ch vi·∫øt n√≥ m·ªôt c√°ch th·ªß c√¥ng ƒë·ªÉ kh√°m ph√° v·ªÅ x·ª≠ l√Ω l·ªói; ·ªü cu·ªëi, ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω cho th·∫•y c√°ch vi·∫øt ng·∫Øn g·ªçn h∆°n. H√£y xem ki·ªÉu tr·∫£ v·ªÅ c·ªßa h√†m tr∆∞·ªõc ti√™n: Result<String, io::Error>. ƒêi·ªÅu n√†y c√≥ nghƒ©a l√† h√†m tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã c·ªßa ki·ªÉu Result<T, E> v·ªõi tham s·ªë T ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒëi·ªÅn v√†o v·ªõi ki·ªÉu c·ª• th·ªÉ String, v√† ki·ªÉu E ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒëi·ªÅn v√†o v·ªõi ki·ªÉu c·ª• th·ªÉ io::Error.

N·∫øu h√†m n√†y th√†nh c√¥ng m√† kh√¥ng c√≥ v·∫•n ƒë·ªÅ g√¨, code g·ªçi h√†m n√†y s·∫Ω nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Ok ch·ª©a m·ªôt String - username m√† h√†m n√†y ƒë·ªçc t·ª´ file. N·∫øu h√†m n√†y g·∫∑p b·∫•t k·ª≥ v·∫•n ƒë·ªÅ n√†o, code g·ªçi h√†m s·∫Ω nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Err ch·ª©a m·ªôt th·ªÉ hi·ªán c·ªßa io::Error ch·ª©a th√¥ng tin chi ti·∫øt v·ªÅ v·∫•n ƒë·ªÅ. Ch√∫ng ta ch·ªçn io::Error l√† ki·ªÉu tr·∫£ v·ªÅ c·ªßa h√†m n√†y v√¨ ƒë√≥ ch√≠nh l√† ki·ªÉu c·ªßa gi√° tr·ªã l·ªói tr·∫£ v·ªÅ t·ª´ c·∫£ hai ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông m√† ch√∫ng ta g·ªçi trong th√¢n h√†m n√†y c√≥ th·ªÉ g·∫∑p l·ªói: h√†m File::open v√† ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c read_to_string.

Th√¢n h√†m b·∫Øt ƒë·∫ßu b·∫±ng c√°ch g·ªçi h√†m File::open. Sau ƒë√≥ ch√∫ng ta x·ª≠ l√Ω gi√° tr·ªã Result v·ªõi m·ªôt match gi·ªëng nh∆∞ match trong Listing 9-4. N·∫øu File::open th√†nh c√¥ng, file handle trong bi·∫øn m·∫´u file tr·ªü th√†nh gi√° tr·ªã trong bi·∫øn username_file v√† h√†m ti·∫øp t·ª•c. Trong tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p Err, thay v√¨ g·ªçi panic!, ch√∫ng ta s·ª≠ d·ª•ng t·ª´ kh√≥a return ƒë·ªÉ tr·∫£ v·ªÅ s·ªõm v√† tr·∫£ v·ªÅ gi√° tr·ªã l·ªói t·ª´ File::open, gi·ªù ƒë√¢y trong bi·∫øn m·∫´u e, v·ªÅ code g·ªçi h√†m nh∆∞ l√† gi√° tr·ªã l·ªói c·ªßa h√†m n√†y.

N√™n n·∫øu ch√∫ng ta c√≥ m·ªôt file handle trong username_file, ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω t·∫°o m·ªôt bi·∫øn ki√™u String m·ªõi v·ªõi t√™n username v√† g·ªçi ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c read_to_string c·ªßa file handle trong username_file ƒë·ªÉ ƒë·ªçc n·ªôi dung c·ªßa file v√†o username. Ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c read_to_string c≈©ng tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt Result v√¨ n√≥ c√≥ th·ªÉ g·∫∑p l·ªói, d√π File::open ƒë√£ th√†nh c√¥ng. V√¨ v·∫≠y ch√∫ng ta c·∫ßn m·ªôt match kh√°c ƒë·ªÉ x·ª≠ l√Ω Result: n·∫øu read_to_string th√†nh c√¥ng, th√¨ h√†m c·ªßa ch√∫ng ta ƒë√£ th√†nh c√¥ng, v√† ch√∫ng ta tr·∫£ v·ªÅ username t·ª´ file hi·ªán t·∫°i trong username ƒë∆∞·ª£c b·ªçc trong m·ªôt Ok. N·∫øu read_to_string g·∫∑p l·ªói, ch√∫ng ta tr·∫£ v·ªÅ gi√° tr·ªã l·ªói theo c√°ch gi·ªëng nh∆∞ ch√∫ng ta tr·∫£ v·ªÅ gi√° tr·ªã l·ªói trong match x·ª≠ l√Ω gi√° tr·ªã tr·∫£ v·ªÅ c·ªßa File::open. Tuy nhi√™n, ch√∫ng ta kh√¥ng c·∫ßn ph·∫£i n√≥i r√µ return, v√¨ ƒë√¢y l√† bi·ªÉu th·ª©c cu·ªëi c√πng trong h√†m.

ƒêo·∫°n code g·ªçi h√†m n√†y s·∫Ω x·ª≠ l√Ω vi·ªác nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Ok ch·ª©a m·ªôt username ho·∫∑c m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Err ch·ª©a m·ªôt io::Error. N√≥ ph·ª• thu·ªôc v√†o code g·ªçi h√†m ƒë·ªÉ quy·∫øt ƒë·ªãnh l√†m g√¨ v·ªõi nh·ªØng gi√° tr·ªã n√†y. N·∫øu code g·ªçi h√†m nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Err, n√≥ c√≥ th·ªÉ g·ªçi panic! v√† crash ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh, s·ª≠ d·ª•ng m·ªôt username m·∫∑c ƒë·ªãnh, ho·∫∑c t√¨m ki·∫øm username t·ª´ m·ªôt n∆°i kh√°c ngo√†i file, v√≠ d·ª•. Ch√∫ng ta kh√¥ng c√≥ ƒë·ªß th√¥ng tin v·ªÅ vi·ªác code g·ªçi h√†m th·ª±c s·ª± mu·ªën l√†m g√¨, v√¨ v·∫≠y ch√∫ng ta truy·ªÅn t·∫•t c·∫£ th√¥ng tin th√†nh c√¥ng ho·∫∑c l·ªói l√™n tr√™n ƒë·ªÉ code g·ªçi h√†m x·ª≠ l√Ω ph√π h·ª£p.

Ph∆∞∆°ng ph√°p truy·ªÅn l·ªói n√†y r·∫•t ph·ªï bi·∫øn trong Rust, v√¨ v·∫≠y Rust cung c·∫•p ph√©p to√°n d·∫•u h·ªèi ? ƒë·ªÉ l√†m cho vi·ªác n√†y d·ªÖ d√†ng h∆°n.

A Shortcut for Propagating Errors: the ? Operator

Listing 9-7 ch·ªâ ra m·ªôt c√°ch code c·ªßa read_username_from_file c√≥ c√πng ch·ª©c nƒÉng nh∆∞ trong Listing 9-6, nh∆∞ng c√°ch code n√†y s·ª≠ d·ª•ng ph√©p to√°n ?.

Filename: src/main.rs

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
use std::fs::File;
use std::io::{self, Read};

fn read_username_from_file() -> Result<String, io::Error> {
    let mut username_file = File::open("hello.txt")?;
    let mut username = String::new();
    username_file.read_to_string(&mut username)?;
    Ok(username)
}
}

Listing 9-7: M·ªôt h√†m tr·∫£ v·ªÅ l·ªói cho code g·ªçi h√†m s·ª≠ d·ª•ng ph√©p to√°n ?

Ph√©p to√°n ? ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a ƒë·ªÉ ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông g·∫ßn nh∆∞ gi·ªëng nh∆∞ c√°c bi·ªÉu th·ª©c match m√† ch√∫ng ta ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a ƒë·ªÉ x·ª≠ l√Ω c√°c gi√° tr·ªã Result trong Listing 9-6. N·∫øu gi√° tr·ªã c·ªßa Result l√† Ok, gi√° tr·ªã b√™n trong Ok s·∫Ω ƒë∆∞·ª£c tr·∫£ v·ªÅ t·ª´ bi·ªÉu th·ª©c n√†y, v√† ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh s·∫Ω ti·∫øp t·ª•c. N·∫øu gi√° tr·ªã l√† Err, Err s·∫Ω ƒë∆∞·ª£c tr·∫£ v·ªÅ tr·∫£ v·ªÅ s·ªõm v√† k·∫øt th√∫c h√†m, gi·ªëng c√°ch ch√∫ng ta d√πng return.

C√≥ m·ªôt s·ª± kh√°c bi·ªát gi·ªØa vi·ªác bi·ªÉu th·ª©c match t·ª´ Listing 9-6 l√†m g√¨ v√† vi·ªác ph√©p to√°n ? l√†m g√¨: c√°c gi√° tr·ªã l·ªói m√† c√≥ ph√©p to√°n ? ƒë∆∞·ª£c g·ªçi s·∫Ω ƒëi qua h√†m from, ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a trong trait From c·ªßa th∆∞ vi·ªán chu·∫©n, ƒë∆∞·ª£c s·ª≠ d·ª•ng ƒë·ªÉ chuy·ªÉn ƒë·ªïi gi√° tr·ªã t·ª´ m·ªôt ki·ªÉu th√†nh m·ªôt ki·ªÉu kh√°c. Khi ph√©p to√°n ? g·ªçi h√†m from, ki·ªÉu l·ªói nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c s·∫Ω ƒë∆∞·ª£c chuy·ªÉn ƒë·ªïi th√†nh ki·ªÉu l·ªói ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a trong ki·ªÉu tr·∫£ v·ªÅ c·ªßa h√†m hi·ªán t·∫°i. ƒêi·ªÅu n√†y r·∫•t h·ªØu √≠ch khi m·ªôt h√†m tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt ki·ªÉu l·ªói ƒë·ªÉ bi·ªÉu di·ªÖn t·∫•t c·∫£ c√°c c√°ch m√† m·ªôt h√†m c√≥ th·ªÉ th·∫•t b·∫°i, ngay c·∫£ khi c√°c ph·∫ßn c√≥ th·ªÉ th·∫•t b·∫°i v√¨ nhi·ªÅu l√Ω do kh√°c nhau.

V√≠ d·ª•, ch√∫ng ta c√≥ th·ªÉ thay ƒë·ªïi h√†m read_username_from_file trong Listing 9-7 ƒë·ªÉ tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt ki·ªÉu l·ªói t√πy ch·ªânh ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë·∫∑t t√™n l√† OurError m√† ch√∫ng ta ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a. N·∫øu ch√∫ng ta c≈©ng ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a impl From<io::Error> for OurError ƒë·ªÉ t·∫°o m·ªôt th·ªÉ hi·ªán c·ªßa OurError t·ª´ m·ªôt io::Error, th√¨ ph√©p to√°n ? s·∫Ω g·ªçi from v√† chuy·ªÉn ƒë·ªïi ki·ªÉu l·ªói m√† kh√¥ng c·∫ßn th√™m b·∫•t k√¨ ƒëo·∫°n m√£ n√†o v√†o h√†m.

Trong ng·ªØ c·∫£nh c·ªßa Listing 9-7, ph√©p to√°n ? ·ªü cu·ªëi l·ªùi g·ªçi File::open s·∫Ω tr·∫£ v·ªÅ gi√° tr·ªã b√™n trong m·ªôt Ok cho bi·∫øn username_file. N·∫øu x·∫£y ra l·ªói, ph√©p to√°n ? s·∫Ω tr·∫£ v·ªÅ s·ªõm v√† tr·∫£ b·∫•t k√¨ gi√° tr·ªã Err n√†o cho code g·ªçi h√†m. ƒêi·ªÅu ƒë√≥ c≈©ng ƒë∆∞·ª£c √°p d·ª•ng cho ph√©p to√°n ? ·ªü cu·ªëi l·ªùi g·ªçi read_to_string.

Ph√©p to√°n ? lo·∫°i b·ªè r·∫•t nhi·ªÅu ƒëo·∫°n m√£ l·∫∑p ƒëi v√† l√†m cho vi·ªác tri·ªÉn khai h√†m tr·ªü n√™n ƒë∆°n gi·∫£n h∆°n. Ch√∫ng ta c√≥ th·ªÉ r√∫t ng·∫Øn ƒëo·∫°n m√£ n√†y th√™m b·∫±ng c√°ch li√™n ti·∫øp g·ªçi c√°c ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c ngay sau ph√©p to√°n ?, nh∆∞ trong Listing 9-8.

Filename: src/main.rs

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
use std::fs::File;
use std::io::{self, Read};

fn read_username_from_file() -> Result<String, io::Error> {
    let mut username = String::new();

    File::open("hello.txt")?.read_to_string(&mut username)?;

    Ok(username)
}
}

Listing 9-8: Li√™n ti·∫øp g·ªçi c√°c ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c sau ph√©p to√°n ?

Ch√∫ng ta t·∫°o m·ªôt bi·∫øn String t√™n username ·ªü ƒë·∫ßu h√†m; ph·∫ßn ƒë√≥ kh√¥ng thay ƒë·ªïi. Thay v√¨ t·∫°o m·ªôt bi·∫øn username_file, ch√∫ng ta li√™n ti·∫øp g·ªçi ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c read_to_string tr·ª±c ti·∫øp tr√™n k·∫øt qu·∫£ c·ªßa File::open("hello.txt")?. Ch√∫ng ta v·∫´n c√≥ m·ªôt ? ·ªü cu·ªëi l·ªùi g·ªçi read_to_string v√† ch√∫ng ta v·∫´n tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Ok ch·ª©a username khi c·∫£ File::open v√† read_to_string th√†nh c√¥ng thay v√¨ tr·∫£ v·ªÅ l·ªói. Ch·ª©c nƒÉng v·∫´n gi·ªëng nh∆∞ trong Listing 9-6 v√† Listing 9-7; ƒë√¢y ch·ªâ l√† m·ªôt c√°ch kh√°c, d·ªÖ d√πng h∆°n ƒë·ªÉ vi·∫øt n√≥.

Listing 9-9 cho th·∫•y m·ªôt c√°ch ƒë·ªÉ l√†m cho ƒëo·∫°n m√£ n√†y ng·∫Øn h∆°n b·∫±ng c√°ch s·ª≠ d·ª•ng fs::read_to_string.

Filename: src/main.rs

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
use std::fs;
use std::io;

fn read_username_from_file() -> Result<String, io::Error> {
    fs::read_to_string("hello.txt")
}
}

Listing 9-9: S·ª≠ d·ª•ng fs::read_to_string thay v√¨ m·ªü v√† sau ƒë√≥ ƒë·ªçc file

ƒê·ªçc m·ªôt file v√†o m·ªôt chu·ªói l√† m·ªôt thao t√°c r·∫•t ph·ªï bi·∫øn, v√¨ v·∫≠y th∆∞ vi·ªán chu·∫©n cung c·∫•p m·ªôt h√†m ti·ªán l·ª£i fs::read_to_string ƒë·ªÉ m·ªü file, t·∫°o m·ªôt String m·ªõi, ƒë·ªçc n·ªôi dung c·ªßa file, ƒë·∫∑t n·ªôi dung v√†o String ƒë√≥ v√† tr·∫£ v·ªÅ n√≥. ƒê∆∞∆°ng nhi√™n, s·ª≠ d·ª•ng fs::read_to_string kh√¥ng cho ch√∫ng ta c∆° h·ªôi ƒë·ªÉ gi·∫£i th√≠ch t·∫•t c·∫£ c√°c x·ª≠ l√Ω l·ªói, v√¨ v·∫≠y ch√∫ng ta ƒë√£ l√†m theo c√°ch d√†i h∆°n tr∆∞·ªõc.

Where The ? Operator Can Be Used

To√°n t·ª≠ ? ch·ªâ c√≥ th·ªÉ ƒë∆∞·ª£c s·ª≠ d·ª•ng trong c√°c h√†m m√† ki·ªÉu tr·∫£ v·ªÅ l√† t∆∞∆°ng th√≠ch v·ªõi gi√° tr·ªã m√† ? ƒë∆∞·ª£c s·ª≠ d·ª•ng. ƒêi·ªÅu n√†y l√† b·ªüi v√¨ to√°n t·ª≠ ? ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a ƒë·ªÉ th·ª±c hi·ªán m·ªôt y√™u c·∫ßu tr·∫£ v·ªÅ s·ªõm c·ªßa m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã ra kh·ªèi h√†m, c√πng m·ªôt c√°ch nh∆∞ bi·ªÉu th·ª©c match m√† ch√∫ng ta ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a trong Listing 9-6. Trong Listing 9-6, match s·ª≠ d·ª•ng m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Result, v√† tr·∫£ v·ªÅ s·ªõm m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Err(e). Ki·ªÉu tr·∫£ v·ªÅ c·ªßa h√†m ph·∫£i l√† m·ªôt Result ƒë·ªÉ n√≥ t∆∞∆°ng th√≠ch v·ªõi tr·∫£ v·ªÅ s·ªõm c·ªßa l·ªánh return.

Trong Listing 9-10, h√£y xem l·ªói m√† ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c n·∫øu ch√∫ng ta s·ª≠ d·ª•ng to√°n t·ª≠ ? trong m·ªôt h√†m main v·ªõi ki·ªÉu tr·∫£ v·ªÅ kh√¥ng t∆∞∆°ng th√≠ch v·ªõi ki·ªÉu c·ªßa gi√° tr·ªã m√† ch√∫ng ta s·ª≠ d·ª•ng ?:

Filename: src/main.rs

use std::fs::File;

fn main() {
    let greeting_file = File::open("hello.txt")?;
}

Listing 9-10: C·ªë g·∫Øng s·ª≠ d·ª•ng ? trong h√†m main tr·∫£ v·ªÅ () s·∫Ω kh√¥ng bi√™n d·ªãch ƒë∆∞·ª£c

ƒêo·∫°n code n√†y m·ªü m·ªôt file, c√≥ th·ªÉ s·∫Ω th·∫•t b·∫°i. To√°n t·ª≠ ? theo sau gi√° tr·ªã Result ƒë∆∞·ª£c tr·∫£ v·ªÅ b·ªüi File::open, nh∆∞ng h√†m main n√†y c√≥ ki·ªÉu tr·∫£ v·ªÅ l√† (), kh√¥ng ph·∫£i Result. Khi ch√∫ng ta bi√™n d·ªãch ƒëo·∫°n code n√†y, ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c l·ªói nh∆∞ sau:

$ cargo run
   Compiling error-handling v0.1.0 (file:///projects/error-handling)
error[E0277]: the `?` operator can only be used in a function that returns `Result` or `Option` (or another type that implements `FromResidual`)
 --> src/main.rs:4:48
  |
3 | fn main() {
  | --------- this function should return `Result` or `Option` to accept `?`
4 |     let greeting_file = File::open("hello.txt")?;
  |                                                ^ cannot use the `?` operator in a function that returns `()`
  |
  = help: the trait `FromResidual<Result<Infallible, std::io::Error>>` is not implemented for `()`

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
error: could not compile `error-handling` due to previous error

L·ªói n√†y ch·ªâ ra r·∫±ng ch√∫ng ta ch·ªâ ƒë∆∞·ª£c ph√©p s·ª≠ d·ª•ng to√°n t·ª≠ ? trong m·ªôt h√†m tr·∫£ v·ªÅ Result, Option, ho·∫∑c m·ªôt ki·ªÉu kh√°c m√† n√≥ tri·ªÉn khai FromResidual.

ƒê·ªÉ s·ª≠a l·ªói, ch√∫ng ta c√≥ hai l·ª±a ch·ªçn. L·ª±a ch·ªçn ƒë·∫ßu ti√™n l√† thay ƒë·ªïi ki·ªÉu tr·∫£ v·ªÅ c·ªßa h√†m ƒë·ªÉ t∆∞∆°ng th√≠ch v·ªõi gi√° tr·ªã m√† ch√∫ng ta ƒëang s·ª≠ d·ª•ng to√°n t·ª≠ ? trong khi kh√¥ng c√≥ gi·ªõi h·∫°n n√†o ngƒÉn c·∫£n ƒëi·ªÅu ƒë√≥. C√°ch kh√°c l√† s·ª≠ d·ª•ng m·ªôt match ho·∫∑c m·ªôt trong c√°c ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c c·ªßa Result<T, E> ƒë·ªÉ x·ª≠ l√Ω Result<T, E> theo c√°ch ph√π h·ª£p.

L·ªói c√≤n n√≥i r·∫±ng ? c√≥ th·ªÉ ƒë∆∞·ª£c s·ª≠ d·ª•ng v·ªõi gi√° tr·ªã Option<T> c≈©ng nh∆∞ v·∫≠y. Gi·ªëng nh∆∞ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng ? tr√™n Result, ch√∫ng ta ch·ªâ c√≥ th·ªÉ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng ? tr√™n Option trong m·ªôt h√†m tr·∫£ v·ªÅ Option. H√†nh vi c·ªßa to√°n t·ª≠ ? khi ƒë∆∞·ª£c g·ªçi tr√™n m·ªôt Option<T> t∆∞∆°ng t·ª± nh∆∞ h√†nh vi c·ªßa n√≥ khi ƒë∆∞·ª£c g·ªçi tr√™n m·ªôt Result<T, E>: n·∫øu gi√° tr·ªã l√† None, None s·∫Ω ƒë∆∞·ª£c tr·∫£ v·ªÅ s·ªõm t·ª´ h√†m t·∫°i ƒëi·ªÉm ƒë√≥. N·∫øu gi√° tr·ªã l√† Some, gi√° tr·ªã b√™n trong Some s·∫Ω l√† gi√° tr·ªã k·∫øt qu·∫£ c·ªßa bi·ªÉu th·ª©c v√† h√†m s·∫Ω ti·∫øp t·ª•c. Listing 9-11 c√≥ m·ªôt v√≠ d·ª• v·ªÅ m·ªôt h√†m t√¨m k√Ω t·ª± cu·ªëi c√πng c·ªßa d√≤ng ƒë·∫ßu ti√™n trong vƒÉn b·∫£n cho tr∆∞·ªõc:

fn last_char_of_first_line(text: &str) -> Option<char> {
    text.lines().next()?.chars().last()
}

fn main() {
    assert_eq!(
        last_char_of_first_line("Hello, world\nHow are you today?"),
        Some('d')
    );

    assert_eq!(last_char_of_first_line(""), None);
    assert_eq!(last_char_of_first_line("\nhi"), None);
}

Listing 9-11: S·ª≠ d·ª•ng to√°n t·ª≠ ? tr√™n m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Option<T>

H√†m n√†y tr·∫£ v·ªÅ Option<char> v√¨ c√≥ th·ªÉ c√≥ m·ªôt k√Ω t·ª± ·ªü ƒë√≥, nh∆∞ng c≈©ng c√≥ th·ªÉ kh√¥ng c√≥. Code n√†y l·∫•y ƒëo·∫°n chu·ªói text v√† g·ªçi ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c lines tr√™n n√≥, n√≥ s·∫Ω tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt iterator (v√≤ng l·∫∑p) tr√™n c√°c d√≤ng trong chu·ªói. V√¨ h√†m n√†y mu·ªën xem x√©t d√≤ng ƒë·∫ßu ti√™n, n√≥ g·ªçi next tr√™n iterator ƒë·ªÉ l·∫•y gi√° tr·ªã ƒë·∫ßu ti√™n t·ª´ iterator. N·∫øu text l√† m·ªôt chu·ªói r·ªóng, cu·ªôc g·ªçi next n√†y s·∫Ω tr·∫£ v·ªÅ None, trong tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p n√†y ch√∫ng ta s·ª≠ d·ª•ng ? ƒë·ªÉ d·ª´ng v√† tr·∫£ v·ªÅ None t·ª´ last_char_of_first_line. N·∫øu text kh√¥ng ph·∫£i l√† m·ªôt chu·ªói r·ªóng, next s·∫Ω tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Some ch·ª©a m·ªôt ƒëo·∫°n chu·ªói c·ªßa d√≤ng ƒë·∫ßu ti√™n trong text.

? tr√≠ch xu·∫•t ƒëo·∫°n chu·ªói, v√† ch√∫ng ta c√≥ th·ªÉ g·ªçi chars tr√™n ƒëo·∫°n chu·ªói ƒë√≥ ƒë·ªÉ l·∫•y m·ªôt iterator (v√≤ng l·∫∑p) c·ªßa c√°c k√Ω t·ª± trong ƒëo·∫°n chu·ªói. Ch√∫ng ta quan t√¢m ƒë·∫øn k√Ω t·ª± cu·ªëi c√πng trong d√≤ng ƒë·∫ßu ti√™n n√†y, v√¨ v·∫≠y ch√∫ng ta g·ªçi last ƒë·ªÉ tr·∫£ v·ªÅ item cu·ªëi c√πng trong iterator. ƒê√¢y l√† m·ªôt Option v√¨ c√≥ th·ªÉ d√≤ng ƒë·∫ßu ti√™n l√† m·ªôt chu·ªói r·ªóng, v√≠ d·ª• n·∫øu text b·∫Øt ƒë·∫ßu v·ªõi m·ªôt d√≤ng tr·∫Øng nh∆∞ng c√≥ c√°c k√Ω t·ª± tr√™n c√°c d√≤ng kh√°c, nh∆∞ trong "\nhi". Tuy nhi√™n, n·∫øu c√≥ m·ªôt k√Ω t·ª± cu·ªëi c√πng tr√™n d√≤ng ƒë·∫ßu ti√™n, n√≥ s·∫Ω ƒë∆∞·ª£c tr·∫£ v·ªÅ trong bi·∫øn Some. To√°n t·ª≠ ? ·ªü gi·ªØa cung c·∫•p cho ch√∫ng ta m·ªôt c√°ch ng·∫Øn g·ªçn ƒë·ªÉ bi·ªÉu th·ªã logic n√†y, cho ph√©p ch√∫ng ta th·ª±c hi·ªán h√†m trong m·ªôt d√≤ng. N·∫øu ch√∫ng ta kh√¥ng th·ªÉ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng to√°n t·ª≠ ? tr√™n Option, ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω ph·∫£i th·ª±c hi·ªán logic n√†y b·∫±ng c√°ch s·ª≠ d·ª•ng nhi·ªÅu ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c g·ªçi h∆°n ho·∫∑c m·ªôt bi·ªÉu th·ª©c match.

L∆∞u √Ω r·∫±ng b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng to√°n t·ª≠ ? tr√™n m·ªôt Result trong m·ªôt h√†m tr·∫£ v·ªÅ Result, v√† b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng to√°n t·ª≠ ? tr√™n m·ªôt Option trong m·ªôt h√†m tr·∫£ v·ªÅ Option, nh∆∞ng b·∫°n kh√¥ng th·ªÉ k·∫øt h·ª£p v√† ph·ªëi h·ª£p. To√°n t·ª≠ ? s·∫Ω kh√¥ng t·ª± ƒë·ªông chuy·ªÉn ƒë·ªïi m·ªôt Result th√†nh m·ªôt Option ho·∫∑c ng∆∞·ª£c l·∫°i; trong nh·ªØng tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p ƒë√≥, b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng c√°c ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c nh∆∞ ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c ok tr√™n Result ho·∫∑c ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c ok_or tr√™n Option ƒë·ªÉ th·ª±c hi·ªán chuy·ªÉn ƒë·ªïi m·ªôt c√°ch r√µ r√†ng.

Hi·ªán t·∫°i, t·∫•t c·∫£ c√°c h√†m main m√† ch√∫ng ta ƒë√£ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng tr·∫£ v·ªÅ (). H√†m main ƒë·∫∑c bi·ªát b·ªüi v√¨ n√≥ l√† ƒëi·ªÉm v√†o (entry point) v√† ra c·ªßa c√°c ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh th·ª±c thi, v√† c√≥ nh·ªØng h·∫°n ch·∫ø v·ªÅ ki·ªÉu tr·∫£ v·ªÅ c·ªßa n√≥ ƒë·ªÉ c√°c ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông nh∆∞ mong ƒë·ª£i.

May m·∫Øn thay, main c≈©ng c√≥ th·ªÉ tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt Result<(), E>. Listing 9-12 c√≥ code t·ª´ Listing 9-10 nh∆∞ng ƒë√£ thay ƒë·ªïi ki·ªÉu tr·∫£ v·ªÅ c·ªßa main th√†nh Result<(), Box<dyn Error>> v√† th√™m m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã tr·∫£ v·ªÅ Ok(()) v√†o cu·ªëi. Code n√†y s·∫Ω b√¢y gi·ªù ƒë∆∞·ª£c bi√™n d·ªãch:

use std::error::Error;
use std::fs::File;

fn main() -> Result<(), Box<dyn Error>> {
    let greeting_file = File::open("hello.txt")?;

    Ok(())
}

Listing 9-12: ƒê·ªïi main ƒë·ªÉ tr·∫£ v·ªÅ Result<(), E> cho ph√©p s·ª≠ d·ª•ng to√°n t·ª≠ ? tr√™n c√°c gi√° tr·ªã Result

Ki·ªÉu Box<dyn Error> l√† m·ªôt trait object, m√† ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω n√≥i v·ªÅ n√≥ trong ph·∫ßn ‚ÄúUsing Trait Objects that Allow for Values of Different Types‚Äù trong Ch∆∞∆°ng 17. Hi·ªán t·∫°i, b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ ƒë·ªçc Box<dyn Error> l√† ‚Äúb·∫•t k·ª≥ lo·∫°i l·ªói n√†o‚Äù. S·ª≠ d·ª•ng ? tr√™n m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Result trong m·ªôt h√†m main v·ªõi ki·ªÉu l·ªói Box<dyn Error> ƒë∆∞·ª£c cho ph√©p, b·ªüi v√¨ n√≥ cho ph√©p b·∫•t k·ª≥ gi√° tr·ªã Err n√†o ƒë∆∞·ª£c tr·∫£ v·ªÅ s·ªõm. D√π cho ph·∫ßn th√¢n c·ªßa h√†m main n√†y s·∫Ω ch·ªâ tr·∫£ v·ªÅ l·ªói c·ªßa ki·ªÉu std::io::Error, b·∫±ng c√°ch x√°c ƒë·ªãnh Box<dyn Error>, ki·ªÉu n√†y s·∫Ω ti·∫øp t·ª•c ƒë√∫ng ngay c·∫£ khi th√™m code m√† tr·∫£ v·ªÅ c√°c l·ªói kh√°c v√†o ph·∫ßn th√¢n c·ªßa main.

Khi h√†m main tr·∫£ v·ªÅ Result<(), E>, ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh s·∫Ω tho√°t v·ªõi m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã 0 n·∫øu main tr·∫£ v·ªÅ Ok(()) v√† s·∫Ω tho√°t v·ªõi m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã kh√°c kh√¥ng ph·∫£i 0 n·∫øu main tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Err. C√°c ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh ƒë∆∞·ª£c vi·∫øt b·∫±ng C tr·∫£ v·ªÅ c√°c s·ªë nguy√™n khi tho√°t: c√°c ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh tho√°t th√†nh c√¥ng tr·∫£ v·ªÅ s·ªë nguy√™n 0, v√† c√°c ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh b·ªã l·ªói tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt s·ªë nguy√™n kh√°c kh√¥ng ph·∫£i 0. Rust c≈©ng tr·∫£ v·ªÅ c√°c s·ªë nguy√™n t·ª´ c√°c ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh ƒë·ªÉ t∆∞∆°ng th√≠ch v·ªõi quy ∆∞·ªõc n√†y.

H√†m main c√≥ th·ªÉ tr·∫£ v·ªÅ b·∫•t k·ª≥ ki·ªÉu n√†o th·ª±c thi the std::process::Termination trait, m√† ch·ª©a m·ªôt h√†m report tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt ExitCode. H√£y xem t√†i li·ªáu th∆∞ vi·ªán chu·∫©n ƒë·ªÉ bi·∫øt th√™m th√¥ng tin v·ªÅ vi·ªác th·ª±c thi trait Termination cho c√°c ki·ªÉu c·ªßa b·∫°n.

B√¢y gi·ªù ch√∫ng ta ƒë√£ th·∫£o lu·∫≠n v·ªÅ chi ti·∫øt v·ªÅ vi·ªác g·ªçi panic! ho·∫∑c tr·∫£ v·ªÅ Result, h√£y tr·ªü l·∫°i v·ªÅ ch·ªß ƒë·ªÅ l√†m th·∫ø n√†o ƒë·ªÉ quy·∫øt ƒë·ªãnh s·ª≠ d·ª•ng c√°i n√†o trong c√°c tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p c·ª• th·ªÉ.

To panic! or Not to panic!

Khi n√†o b·∫°n n√™n d√πng panic v√† khi n√†o n√™n return v·ªÅ Result? Khi code panic, th√¨ kh√¥ng c√≥ c√°ch n√†o ƒë·ªÉ kh√¥i ph·ª•c l·∫°i. B·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ d√πng panic cho b·∫•t k·ª≥ tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p l·ªói n√†o, d√π c√≥ th·ªÉ kh√¥i ph·ª•c l·∫°i hay kh√¥ng, nh∆∞ng b·∫°n s·∫Ω ph·∫£i ƒë∆∞a ra quy·∫øt ƒë·ªãnh r·∫±ng m·ªôt tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p l√† kh√¥ng th·ªÉ kh√¥i ph·ª•c l·∫°i ƒë∆∞·ª£c, ƒë·ªëi v·ªõi code g·ªçi h√†m. Khi b·∫°n ch·ªçn tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Result, b·∫°n s·∫Ω cho ph√©p code g·ªçi h√†m c√≥ c√°c l·ª±a ch·ªçn. Code g·ªçi h√†m c√≥ th·ªÉ ch·ªçn c√°ch kh√¥i ph·ª•c l·∫°i m·ªôt c√°ch ph√π h·ª£p v·ªõi tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p c·ªßa n√≥, ho·∫∑c n√≥ c√≥ th·ªÉ quy·∫øt ƒë·ªãnh r·∫±ng m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Err trong tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p n√†y l√† kh√¥ng th·ªÉ kh√¥i ph·ª•c l·∫°i ƒë∆∞·ª£c, v√¨ v·∫≠y n√≥ c√≥ th·ªÉ g·ªçi panic v√† chuy·ªÉn m·ªôt l·ªói c√≥ th·ªÉ kh√¥i ph·ª•c l·∫°i th√†nh m·ªôt l·ªói kh√¥ng th·ªÉ kh√¥i ph·ª•c l·∫°i. Do ƒë√≥, tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Result l√† m·ªôt l·ª±a ch·ªçn m·∫∑c ƒë·ªãnh t·ªët khi b·∫°n ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a m·ªôt h√†m c√≥ th·ªÉ g√¢y l·ªói.

Trong c√°c tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p nh∆∞ v√≠ d·ª•, code prototype, v√† c√°c test code, th√¨ vi·∫øt code d√πng panic thay v√¨ tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Result l√† ph√π h·ª£p h∆°n. Ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω t√¨m hi·ªÉu t·∫°i sao nh∆∞ v·∫≠y, sau ƒë√≥ th·∫£o lu·∫≠n v·ªÅ c√°c tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p m√† compiler kh√¥ng th·ªÉ bi·∫øt ƒë∆∞·ª£c r·∫±ng vi·ªác g√¢y l·ªói l√† kh√¥ng th·ªÉ, nh∆∞ng b·∫°n l√† m·ªôt con ng∆∞·ªùi c√≥ th·ªÉ. Ch∆∞∆°ng n√†y s·∫Ω k·∫øt th√∫c v·ªõi m·ªôt s·ªë h∆∞·ªõng d·∫´n chung v·ªÅ c√°ch quy·∫øt ƒë·ªãnh c√≥ n√™n d√πng panic trong code c·ªßa th∆∞ vi·ªán hay kh√¥ng.

Examples, Prototype Code, and Tests

Khi b·∫°n vi·∫øt m·ªôt v√≠ d·ª• ƒë·ªÉ minh ho·∫° m·ªôt kh√°i ni·ªám n√†o ƒë√≥, vi·ªác bao g·ªìm code x·ª≠ l√Ω l·ªói k·ªπ l∆∞·ª°ng c≈©ng c√≥ th·ªÉ l√†m cho v√≠ d·ª• k√©m r√µ r√†ng h∆°n. Trong m·ªôt v√≠ d·ª•, d·ªÖ hi·ªÉu r·∫±ng g·ªçi ƒë·∫øn m·ªôt ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c nh∆∞ unwrap c√≥ th·ªÉ g√¢y l·ªói panic gi·ªëng nh∆∞ l√† m·ªôt b·∫£n thay th·∫ø cho c√°ch b·∫°n mu·ªën ·ª©ng d·ª•ng c·ªßa b·∫°n x·ª≠ l√Ω l·ªói, m√† c√≥ th·ªÉ kh√°c nhau v·ªõi c√°c ph·∫ßn kh√°c trong code c·ªßa b·∫°n.

T∆∞∆°ng t·ª±, ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c unwrap v√† expect r·∫•t h·ªØu √≠ch khi ƒëang prototype, tr∆∞·ªõc khi b·∫°n ƒë√£ s·∫µn s√†ng ƒë·ªÉ quy·∫øt ƒë·ªãnh c√°ch x·ª≠ l√Ω l·ªói. Ch√∫ng ƒë·ªÉ l·∫°i c√°c d·∫•u ch·ªâ r√µ r√†ng trong code c·ªßa b·∫°n khi b·∫°n ƒë√£ s·∫µn s√†ng ƒë·ªÉ l√†m cho ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh c·ªßa b·∫°n m·∫°nh c·ª©ng c√°p h∆°n.

N·∫øu m·ªôt ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c g·ªçi th·∫•t b·∫°i trong m·ªôt test, b·∫°n s·∫Ω mu·ªën to√†n b·ªô test th·∫•t b·∫°i, ngay c·∫£ khi ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c ƒë√≥ kh√¥ng ph·∫£i l√† ch·ª©c nƒÉng ƒëang ƒë∆∞·ª£c test. B·ªüi v√¨ panic! l√† c√°ch ƒë·ªÉ m·ªôt test ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë√°nh d·∫•u l√† th·∫•t b·∫°i, vi·ªác g·ªçi unwrap ho·∫∑c expect ch√≠nh l√† nh·ªØng g√¨ n√™n x·∫£y ra.

Cases in Which You Have More Information Than the Compiler

S·∫Ω l√† ch·∫•p nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c n·∫øu b·∫°n g·ªçi unwrap ho·∫∑c expect khi b·∫°n c√≥ m·ªôt logic kh√°c m√† ƒë·∫£m b·∫£o Result s·∫Ω c√≥ m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Ok, nh∆∞ng logic n√†y kh√¥ng ph·∫£i l√† m·ªôt th·ª© m√† compiler hi·ªÉu ƒë∆∞·ª£c. B·∫°n v·∫´n s·∫Ω c√≥ m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Result m√† b·∫°n c·∫ßn ph·∫£i x·ª≠ l√Ω: b·∫•t k·ª≥ ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông n√†o b·∫°n ƒëang g·ªçi v·∫´n c√≥ th·ªÉ th·∫•t b·∫°i, ngay c·∫£ khi n√≥ l√† v√¥ l√Ω trong tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p c·ª• th·ªÉ c·ªßa b·∫°n. N·∫øu b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ ƒë·∫£m b·∫£o b·∫±ng c√°ch th·ªß c√¥ng ki·ªÉm tra code m√† b·∫°n s·∫Ω kh√¥ng bao gi·ªù c√≥ m·ªôt bi·∫øn th·ªÉ Err, th√¨ n√≥ l√† ho√†n to√†n ch·∫•p nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë·ªÉ g·ªçi unwrap, v√† c√≤n t·ªët h∆°n l√† vi·∫øt l√Ω do b·∫°n nghƒ© b·∫°n s·∫Ω kh√¥ng bao gi·ªù c√≥ m·ªôt bi·∫øn th·ªÉ Err trong vƒÉn b·∫£n expect. ƒê√¢y l√† m·ªôt v√≠ d·ª•:

fn main() {
    use std::net::IpAddr;

    let home: IpAddr = "127.0.0.1"
        .parse()
        .expect("Hardcoded IP address should be valid");
}

Ch√∫ng ta ƒëang t·∫°o m·ªôt instance IpAddr b·∫±ng c√°ch truy·ªÅn v√†o m·ªôt chu·ªói c·ªë ƒë·ªãnh (hardcode). Ch√∫ng ta c√≥ th·ªÉ th·∫•y 127.0.0.1 l√† m·ªôt ƒë·ªãa ch·ªâ IP h·ª£p l·ªá, do ƒë√≥ vi·ªác s·ª≠ d·ª•ng expect ·ªü ƒë√¢y l√† ch·∫•p nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c. Tuy nhi√™n, vi·ªác c√≥ m·ªôt chu·ªói h·ª£p l·ªá c·ªë ƒë·ªãnh kh√¥ng thay ƒë·ªïi ki·ªÉu tr·∫£ v·ªÅ c·ªßa ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c parse: ch√∫ng ta v·∫´n nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã Result, v√† compiler v·∫´n s·∫Ω y√™u c·∫ßu ch√∫ng ta x·ª≠ l√Ω Result nh∆∞ n√≥ c√≥ th·ªÉ c√≥ bi·∫øn th·ªÉ Err v√¨ compiler kh√¥ng ƒë·ªß th√¥ng minh ƒë·ªÉ nh√¨n th·∫•y r·∫±ng chu·ªói n√†y lu√¥n lu√¥n l√† m·ªôt ƒë·ªãa ch·ªâ IP h·ª£p l·ªá. N·∫øu chu·ªói ƒë·ªãa ch·ªâ IP ƒë∆∞·ª£c l·∫•y t·ª´ ng∆∞·ªùi d√πng thay v√¨ ƒë∆∞·ª£c c·ªë ƒë·ªãnh trong ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh v√† do ƒë√≥ c√≥ th·ªÉ c√≥ m·ªôt kh·∫£ nƒÉng th·∫•t b·∫°i, ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω ch·∫Øc ch·∫Øn mu·ªën x·ª≠ l√Ω Result m·ªôt c√°ch linh ho·∫°t h∆°n. Vi·ªác nh·∫Øc nh·ªü r·∫±ng gi·∫£ ƒë·ªãnh n√†y l√† ƒë·ªãa ch·ªâ IP ƒë∆∞·ª£c c·ªë ƒë·ªãnh s·∫Ω l√†m ch√∫ng ta thay ƒë·ªïi expect th√†nh m·ªôt c√°ch x·ª≠ l√Ω l·ªói t·ªët h∆°n n·∫øu trong t∆∞∆°ng lai, ch√∫ng ta c·∫ßn l·∫•y ƒë·ªãa ch·ªâ IP t·ª´ m·ªôt ngu·ªìn kh√°c thay v√¨ ƒë·ªãa ch·ªâ IP c·ªë ƒë·ªãnh.

Guidelines for Error Handling

S·∫Ω t·ªët h∆°n n·∫øu code c·ªßa b·∫°n g·ªçi panic! khi c√≥ th·ªÉ code c·ªßa b·∫°n s·∫Ω g·∫∑p m·ªôt tr·∫°ng th√°i kh√¥ng t·ªët. Trong ng·ªØ c·∫£nh n√†y, m·ªôt tr·∫°ng th√°i kh√¥ng t·ªët (bad state) l√† khi m·ªôt gi·∫£ ƒë·ªãnh (assumption), b·∫£o ƒë·∫£m (guarantee), h·ª£p ƒë·ªìng (contract), ho·∫∑c b·∫•t bi·∫øn (invariant) n√†o ƒë√≥ ƒë√£ b·ªã ph√° v·ª°, nh∆∞ khi c√°c gi√° tr·ªã kh√¥ng h·ª£p l·ªá, gi√° tr·ªã tr√°i ng∆∞·ª£c, ho·∫∑c c√°c gi√° tr·ªã b·ªã thi·∫øu ƒë∆∞·ª£c truy·ªÅn v√†o code c·ªßa b·∫°n - c·ªông v·ªõi m·ªôt ho·∫∑c nhi·ªÅu trong nh·ªØng ƒëi·ªÅu sau:

  • Tr·∫°ng th√°i kh√¥ng t·ªët n√†y l√† m·ªôt ƒëi·ªÅu kh√¥ng mong ƒë·ª£i, kh√°c v·ªõi ƒëi·ªÅu c√≥ th·ªÉ x·∫£y ra th∆∞·ªùng xuy√™n, nh∆∞ ng∆∞·ªùi d√πng nh·∫≠p d·ªØ li·ªáu sai ƒë·ªãnh d·∫°ng.
  • Code c·ªßa b·∫°n sau ƒëi·ªÉm n√†y c·∫ßn ph·∫£i ch·∫Øc r·∫±ng n√≥ kh√¥ng mu·ªën trong tr·∫°ng th√°i kh√¥ng t·ªët n√†y, thay v√¨ ki·ªÉm tra v·∫•n ƒë·ªÅ n√†y ·ªü m·ªói b∆∞·ªõc.
  • Kh√¥ng c√≥ m·ªôt c√°ch n√†o ƒë·ªÉ encode th√¥ng tin n√†y trong c√°c ki·ªÉu m√† b·∫°n s·ª≠ d·ª•ng. Ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω l√†m v√≠ d·ª• v·ªÅ ƒëi·ªÅu n√†y trong ph·∫ßn ‚ÄúEncoding States and Behavior as Types‚Äù c·ªßa ch∆∞∆°ng 17.

N·∫øu ai ƒë√≥ g·ªçi code c·ªßa b·∫°n v√† truy·ªÅn v√†o c√°c gi√° tr·ªã kh√¥ng c√≥ √Ω nghƒ©a, t·ªët nh·∫•t l√† tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt l·ªói n·∫øu b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ ƒë·ªÉ ng∆∞·ªùi d√πng th∆∞ vi·ªán c√≥ th·ªÉ quy·∫øt ƒë·ªãnh h·ªç mu·ªën l√†m g√¨ trong tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p ƒë√≥. Tuy nhi√™n, trong tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p ti·∫øp t·ª•c c√≥ th·ªÉ kh√¥ng an to√†n ho·∫∑c c√≥ h·∫°i, l·ª±a ch·ªçn t·ªët nh·∫•t c√≥ th·ªÉ l√† g·ªçi panic! v√† th√¥ng b√°o cho ng∆∞·ªùi s·ª≠ d·ª•ng th∆∞ vi·ªán c·ªßa b·∫°n v·ªÅ l·ªói trong code c·ªßa h·ªç ƒë·ªÉ h·ªç c√≥ th·ªÉ s·ª≠a ch·ªØa trong qu√° tr√¨nh ph√°t tri·ªÉn. T∆∞∆°ng t·ª±, panic! th∆∞·ªùng ƒë∆∞·ª£c s·ª≠ d·ª•ng n·∫øu b·∫°n ƒëang g·ªçi code b√™n ngo√†i m√† b·∫°n kh√¥ng ki·ªÉm so√°t ƒë∆∞·ª£c v√† n√≥ tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt tr·∫°ng th√°i kh√¥ng h·ª£p l·ªá m√† b·∫°n kh√¥ng th·ªÉ s·ª≠a ƒë∆∞·ª£c.

Tuy nhi√™n, khi th·∫•t b·∫°i l√† c√≥ th·ªÉ d·ª± ƒëo√°n ƒë∆∞·ª£c, s·∫Ω th√≠ch h·ª£p h∆°n ƒë·ªÉ tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt Result h∆°n l√† g·ªçi m·ªôt panic!. V√≠ d·ª• bao g·ªìm m·ªôt b·ªô ph√¢n t√≠ch ƒë∆∞·ª£c cung c·∫•p d·ªØ li·ªáu b·ªã l·ªói ho·∫∑c m·ªôt y√™u c·∫ßu HTTP tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt tr·∫°ng th√°i cho th·∫•y b·∫°n ƒë√£ ƒë·∫°t gi·ªõi h·∫°n t·ªëc ƒë·ªô. Trong nh·ªØng tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p n√†y, tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt Result cho th·∫•y th·∫•t b·∫°i l√† m·ªôt kh·∫£ nƒÉng ƒë∆∞·ª£c d·ª± ƒëo√°n r·∫±ng code g·ªçi ph·∫£i quy·∫øt ƒë·ªãnh c√°ch x·ª≠ l√Ω.

Khi code c·ªßa b·∫°n th·ª±c hi·ªán m·ªôt ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông c√≥ th·ªÉ t·∫°o ra r·ªßi ro cho ng∆∞·ªùi d√πng n·∫øu n√≥ ƒë∆∞·ª£c g·ªçi b·∫±ng c√°ch s·ª≠ d·ª•ng gi√° tr·ªã kh√¥ng h·ª£p l·ªá, code c·ªßa b·∫°n n√™n ki·ªÉm tra gi√° tr·ªã h·ª£p l·ªá tr∆∞·ªõc v√† g·ªçi panic! n·∫øu gi√° tr·ªã kh√¥ng h·ª£p l·ªá. ƒêi·ªÅu n√†y ch·ªß y·∫øu l√† v√¨ l√Ω do an to√†n: c·ªë g·∫Øng th·ª±c hi·ªán c√°c ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông tr√™n d·ªØ li·ªáu kh√¥ng h·ª£p l·ªá c√≥ th·ªÉ ti·∫øp c·∫≠n code c·ªßa b·∫°n v·ªõi c√°c l·ªó h·ªïng b·∫£o m·∫≠t. ƒê√¢y l√† l√Ω do ch√≠nh t·∫°i sao th∆∞ vi·ªán chu·∫©n s·∫Ω g·ªçi panic! n·∫øu b·∫°n c·ªë g·∫Øng truy c·∫≠p b·ªô nh·ªõ ngo√†i ph·∫°m vi: c·ªë g·∫Øng truy c·∫≠p b·ªô nh·ªõ kh√¥ng thu·ªôc c·∫•u tr√∫c d·ªØ li·ªáu hi·ªán t·∫°i l√† m·ªôt v·∫•n ƒë·ªÅ b·∫£o m·∫≠t ph·ªï bi·∫øn. C√°c h√†m th∆∞·ªùng c√≥ h·ª£p ƒë·ªìng (contract): h√†nh vi c·ªßa ch√∫ng ch·ªâ ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë·∫£m b·∫£o n·∫øu ƒë·∫ßu v√†o ƒë√°p ·ª©ng c√°c y√™u c·∫ßu nh·∫•t ƒë·ªãnh. G·ªçi panic! khi vi ph·∫°m h·ª£p ƒë·ªìng l√† h·ª£p l√Ω b·ªüi v√¨ vi ph·∫°m h·ª£p ƒë·ªìng lu√¥n lu√¥n ch·ªâ ra l·ªói ·ªü ph√≠a g·ªçi v√† n√≥ kh√¥ng ph·∫£i l√† m·ªôt lo·∫°i l·ªói b·∫°n mu·ªën code g·ªçi ph·∫£i x·ª≠ l√Ω m·ªôt c√°ch r√µ r√†ng. Th·ª±c ra, kh√¥ng c√≥ c√°ch n√†o cho code g·ªçi ph·ª•c h·ªìi; ng∆∞·ªùi l·∫≠p tr√¨nh vi√™n g·ªçi c·∫ßn ph·∫£i s·ª≠a code. H·ª£p ƒë·ªìng cho m·ªôt h√†m, ƒë·∫∑c bi·ªát l√† khi m·ªôt vi ph·∫°m s·∫Ω g√¢y ra panic!, n√™n ƒë∆∞·ª£c gi·∫£i th√≠ch trong t√†i li·ªáu API cho h√†m ƒë√≥.

Tuy nhi√™n, c√≥ nhi·ªÅu ki·ªÉm tra l·ªói trong t·∫•t c·∫£ c√°c h√†m c·ªßa b·∫°n s·∫Ω r·∫•t d√†i d√≤ng v√† phi·ªÅn ph·ª©c. May m·∫Øn thay, b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng h·ªá th·ªëng ki·ªÉu c·ªßa Rust (v√† v√¨ v·∫≠y l√† ki·ªÉm tra ki·ªÉu ƒë∆∞·ª£c th·ª±c hi·ªán b·ªüi tr√¨nh bi√™n d·ªãch) ƒë·ªÉ th·ª±c hi·ªán nhi·ªÅu ki·ªÉm tra cho b·∫°n. N·∫øu h√†m c·ªßa b·∫°n c√≥ m·ªôt ki·ªÉu c·ª• th·ªÉ l√†m tham s·ªë, b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ ti·∫øp t·ª•c v·ªõi logic code c·ªßa m√¨nh bi·∫øt r·∫±ng tr√¨nh bi√™n d·ªãch ƒë√£ ƒë·∫£m b·∫£o b·∫°n c√≥ m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã h·ª£p l·ªá. V√≠ d·ª•, n·∫øu b·∫°n c√≥ m·ªôt ki·ªÉu thay v√¨ m·ªôt Option, ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh c·ªßa b·∫°n mong ƒë·ª£i s·∫Ω c√≥ g√¨ ƒë√≥ thay v√¨ kh√¥ng c√≥ g√¨. Code c·ªßa b·∫°n sau ƒë√≥ kh√¥ng c·∫ßn ph·∫£i x·ª≠ l√Ω hai tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p cho c√°c bi·∫øn th·ªÉ Some v√† None: n√≥ s·∫Ω ch·ªâ c√≥ m·ªôt tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p cho vi·ªác ch·∫Øc ch·∫Øn c√≥ m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã. Code c·ªë g·∫Øng truy·ªÅn kh√¥ng c√≥ g√¨ cho h√†m c·ªßa b·∫°n s·∫Ω kh√¥ng th·ªÉ bi√™n d·ªãch, v√¨ v·∫≠y h√†m c·ªßa b·∫°n kh√¥ng c·∫ßn ph·∫£i ki·ªÉm tra tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p ƒë√≥ khi ch·∫°y. M·ªôt v√≠ d·ª• kh√°c l√† s·ª≠ d·ª•ng m·ªôt ki·ªÉu s·ªë nguy√™n kh√¥ng d·∫•u nh∆∞ u32, ƒë·∫£m b·∫£o tham s·ªë kh√¥ng bao gi·ªù √¢m.

Creating Custom Types for Validation

L·∫•y √Ω t∆∞·ªüng s·ª≠ d·ª•ng h·ªá th·ªëng ki·ªÉu Rust ƒë·ªÉ ƒë·∫£m b·∫£o ch√∫ng ta c√≥ m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã h·ª£p l·ªá, h∆°n n·ªØa l√† t·∫°o m·ªôt ki·ªÉu t√πy ch·ªânh cho vi·ªác x√°c th·ª±c. Nh·ªõ l·∫°i tr√≤ ch∆°i ƒëo√°n s·ªë trong Ch∆∞∆°ng 2 trong ƒë√≥ code c·ªßa ch√∫ng ta y√™u c·∫ßu ng∆∞·ªùi d√πng ƒëo√°n m·ªôt s·ªë gi·ªØa 1 v√† 100. Ch√∫ng ta kh√¥ng bao gi·ªù x√°c th·ª±c r·∫±ng ƒëo√°n c·ªßa ng∆∞·ªùi d√πng n·∫±m gi·ªØa hai s·ªë n√†y tr∆∞·ªõc khi ki·ªÉm tra n√≥ v·ªõi s·ªë b√≠ m·∫≠t c·ªßa ch√∫ng ta; ch√∫ng ta ch·ªâ x√°c th·ª±c r·∫±ng ƒëo√°n l√† d∆∞∆°ng. Trong tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p n√†y, h·∫≠u qu·∫£ kh√¥ng qu√° nghi√™m tr·ªçng: output c·ªßa ch√∫ng ta c√≥ th·ªÉ "Qu√° cao" ho·∫∑c "Qu√° th·∫•p" v·∫´n s·∫Ω ch√≠nh x√°c. Nh∆∞ng n√≥ s·∫Ω l√† m·ªôt s·ª± c·∫£i thi·ªán c√≥ √≠ch ƒë·ªÉ h∆∞·ªõng d·∫´n ng∆∞·ªùi d√πng ƒë·∫øn c√°c ƒëo√°n h·ª£p l·ªá v√† c√≥ h√†nh vi kh√°c nhau khi ng∆∞·ªùi d√πng ƒëo√°n m·ªôt s·ªë n·∫±m ngo√†i ph·∫°m vi so v·ªõi khi ng∆∞·ªùi d√πng nh·∫≠p, v√≠ d·ª•, c√°c ch·ªØ c√°i thay v√¨ s·ªë.

M·ªôt c√°ch ƒë·ªÉ l√†m ƒëi·ªÅu n√†y l√† ph√¢n t√≠ch ƒëo√°n d∆∞·ªõi d·∫°ng i32 thay v√¨ ch·ªâ u32 ƒë·ªÉ cho ph√©p c√°c s·ªë √¢m, v√† sau ƒë√≥ th√™m m·ªôt ki·ªÉm tra cho s·ªë n·∫±m trong ph·∫°m vi, nh∆∞ sau:

use rand::Rng;
use std::cmp::Ordering;
use std::io;

fn main() {
    println!("Guess the number!");

    let secret_number = rand::thread_rng().gen_range(1..=100);

    loop {
        // --snip--

        println!("Please input your guess.");

        let mut guess = String::new();

        io::stdin()
            .read_line(&mut guess)
            .expect("Failed to read line");

        let guess: i32 = match guess.trim().parse() {
            Ok(num) => num,
            Err(_) => continue,
        };

        if guess < 1 || guess > 100 {
            println!("The secret number will be between 1 and 100.");
            continue;
        }

        match guess.cmp(&secret_number) {
            // --snip--
            Ordering::Less => println!("Too small!"),
            Ordering::Greater => println!("Too big!"),
            Ordering::Equal => {
                println!("You win!");
                break;
            }
        }
    }
}

D√≤ng if ki·ªÉm tra xem gi√° tr·ªã c·ªßa ch√∫ng ta c√≥ n·∫±m ngo√†i ph·∫°m vi hay kh√¥ng, n√≥i v·ªõi ng∆∞·ªùi d√πng v·ªÅ v·∫•n ƒë·ªÅ n√†y, v√† g·ªçi continue ƒë·ªÉ b·∫Øt ƒë·∫ßu v√≤ng l·∫∑p ti·∫øp theo v√† y√™u c·∫ßu m·ªôt ƒëo√°n kh√°c. Sau d√≤ng if, ch√∫ng ta c√≥ th·ªÉ ti·∫øp t·ª•c v·ªõi c√°c s·ª± so s√°nh gi·ªØa guess v√† s·ªë b√≠ m·∫≠t bi·∫øt r·∫±ng guess n·∫±m gi·ªØa 1 v√† 100.

Tuy nhi√™n, ƒë√¢y kh√¥ng ph·∫£i l√† m·ªôt gi·∫£i ph√°p t·ªëi ∆∞u: n·∫øu n√≥ l√† r·∫•t quan tr·ªçng cho ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh ch·ªâ ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông tr√™n c√°c gi√° tr·ªã gi·ªØa 1 v√† 100, v√† n√≥ c√≥ nhi·ªÅu h√†m v·ªõi y√™u c·∫ßu n√†y, c√≥ m·ªôt ki·ªÉm tra nh∆∞ th·∫ø n√†y trong m·ªói h√†m s·∫Ω l√† m·ªôt vi·ªác nh√†m ch√°n (v√† c√≥ th·ªÉ ·∫£nh h∆∞·ªüng ƒë·∫øn hi·ªáu su·∫•t (performance)).

Thay v√†o ƒë√≥, ch√∫ng ta c√≥ th·ªÉ t·∫°o m·ªôt ki·ªÉu m·ªõi v√† ƒë·∫∑t c√°c x√°c th·ª±c trong m·ªôt h√†m ƒë·ªÉ t·∫°o m·ªôt th·ªÉ hi·ªán c·ªßa ki·ªÉu thay v√¨ l·∫∑p l·∫°i c√°c x√°c th·ª±c ·ªü m·ªçi n∆°i. ƒê√≥ l√†m cho an to√†n cho c√°c h√†m s·ª≠ d·ª•ng ki·ªÉu m·ªõi trong ch·ªØ k√Ω c·ªßa ch√∫ng v√† tin t∆∞·ªüng v√†o c√°c gi√° tr·ªã m√† ch√∫ng nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c. Listing 9-13 cho th·∫•y m·ªôt c√°ch ƒë·ªÉ ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a m·ªôt ki·ªÉu Guess s·∫Ω ch·ªâ t·∫°o m·ªôt th·ªÉ hi·ªán c·ªßa Guess n·∫øu h√†m new nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c m·ªôt gi√° tr·ªã gi·ªØa 1 v√† 100.

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
pub struct Guess {
    value: i32,
}

impl Guess {
    pub fn new(value: i32) -> Guess {
        if value < 1 || value > 100 {
            panic!("Guess value must be between 1 and 100, got {}.", value);
        }

        Guess { value }
    }

    pub fn value(&self) -> i32 {
        self.value
    }
}
}

Listing 9-13: M·ªôt ki·ªÉu Guess s·∫Ω ch·ªâ ti·∫øp t·ª•c v·ªõi c√°c gi√° tr·ªã gi·ªØa 1 v√† 100

ƒê·∫ßu ti√™n, ch√∫ng ta ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a m·ªôt struct c√≥ t√™n Guess c√≥ m·ªôt tr∆∞·ªùng c√≥ t√™n value ch·ª©a m·ªôt i32. ƒê√¢y l√† n∆°i s·ªë s·∫Ω ƒë∆∞·ª£c l∆∞u tr·ªØ.

Sau ƒë√≥ ch√∫ng ta hi·ªán th∆∞c m·ªôt h√†m new tr√™n Guess ƒë·ªÉ t·∫°o c√°c instance c·ªßa Guess. H√†m new ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒë·ªãnh nghƒ©a ƒë·ªÉ c√≥ m·ªôt tham s·ªë c√≥ t√™n value c·ªßa ki·ªÉu i32 v√† tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt Guess. Code trong th√¢n h√†m new ki·ªÉm tra value ƒë·ªÉ ch·∫Øc ch·∫Øn n√≥ n·∫±m trong kho·∫£ng t·ª´ 1 ƒë·∫øn 100. N·∫øu value kh√¥ng ƒë·∫°t ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒëi·ªÅu ki·ªán n√†y, ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω g·ªçi m·ªôt panic!, ƒë√≥ s·∫Ω th√¥ng b√°o cho ng∆∞·ªùi l·∫≠p tr√¨nh vi√™n ƒëang vi·∫øt code g·ªçi h√†m n√†y r·∫±ng h·ªç c√≥ m·ªôt l·ªói m√† h·ªç c·∫ßn ph·∫£i s·ª≠a, v√¨ t·∫°o m·ªôt Guess v·ªõi value n·∫±m ngo√†i ph·∫°m vi n√†y s·∫Ω vi ph·∫°m h·ª£p ƒë·ªìng m√† Guess::new ƒëang ph·ª• thu·ªôc v√†o. C√°c ƒëi·ªÅu ki·ªán m√† Guess::new c√≥ th·ªÉ g√¢y ra panic! n√™n ƒë∆∞·ª£c th·∫£o lu·∫≠n trong t√†i li·ªáu API c·ªßa n√≥; ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω th·∫£o lu·∫≠n v·ªÅ c√°c quy ∆∞·ªõc v·ªÅ t√†i li·ªáu trong ch∆∞∆°ng 14. N·∫øu value ƒë·∫°t ƒë∆∞·ª£c ƒëi·ªÅu ki·ªán n√†y, ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω t·∫°o m·ªôt Guess m·ªõi v·ªõi tr∆∞·ªùng value ƒë∆∞·ª£c thi·∫øt l·∫≠p th√†nh tham s·ªë value v√† tr·∫£ v·ªÅ Guess.

Ti·∫øp theo, ch√∫ng ta hi·ªán th·ª±c m·ªôt ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c c√≥ t√™n value m√† m∆∞·ª£n self, kh√¥ng c√≥ b·∫•t k·ª≥ tham s·ªë n√†o kh√°c, v√† tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt i32. Lo·∫°i ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c n√†y ƒë√¥i khi ƒë∆∞·ª£c g·ªçi l√† getter, v√¨ m·ª•c ƒë√≠ch c·ªßa n√≥ l√† ƒë·ªÉ l·∫•y m·ªôt s·ªë d·ªØ li·ªáu t·ª´ c√°c tr∆∞·ªùng c·ªßa n√≥. Ph∆∞∆°ng th·ª©c c√¥ng khai n√†y l√† c·∫ßn thi·∫øt v√¨ tr∆∞·ªùng value c·ªßa Guess struct l√† ri√™ng t∆∞. Quan tr·ªçng l√† tr∆∞·ªùng value ph·∫£i l√† ri√™ng t∆∞ ƒë·ªÉ code s·ª≠ d·ª•ng Guess struct kh√¥ng ƒë∆∞·ª£c ph√©p thi·∫øt l·∫≠p value tr·ª±c ti·∫øp: code b√™n ngo√†i module ph·∫£i s·ª≠ d·ª•ng h√†m Guess::new ƒë·ªÉ t·∫°o m·ªôt th·ªÉ hi·ªán c·ªßa Guess, v√¨ v·∫≠y ƒë·∫£m b·∫£o r·∫±ng kh√¥ng c√≥ c√°ch n√†o cho m·ªôt Guess c√≥ m·ªôt value m√† ch∆∞a ƒë∆∞·ª£c ki·ªÉm tra b·ªüi c√°c ƒëi·ªÅu ki·ªán trong h√†m Guess::new.

M·ªôt h√†m c√≥ m·ªôt tham s·ªë ho·∫∑c tr·∫£ v·ªÅ ch·ªâ c√°c s·ªë t·ª´ 1 ƒë·∫øn 100 c√≥ th·ªÉ sau ƒë√≥ khai b√°o trong ch·ªØ k√Ω (signature) c·ªßa n√≥ r·∫±ng n√≥ nh·∫≠n ho·∫∑c tr·∫£ v·ªÅ m·ªôt Guess thay v√¨ m·ªôt i32 v√† kh√¥ng c·∫ßn ph·∫£i l√†m b·∫•t k·ª≥ ki·ªÉm tra b·ªï sung n√†o trong th√¢n h√†m c·ªßa n√≥.

Summary

X·ª≠ l√Ω l·ªói trong Rust ƒë∆∞·ª£c thi·∫øt k·∫ø ƒë·ªÉ gi√∫p b·∫°n vi·∫øt m√£ c√≥ t√≠nh ·ªïn ƒë·ªãnh cao h∆°n. panic! macro cho bi·∫øt r·∫±ng ch∆∞∆°ng tr√¨nh c·ªßa b·∫°n ƒëang ·ªü m·ªôt tr·∫°ng th√°i n√≥ kh√¥ng th·ªÉ x·ª≠ l√Ω v√† cho ph√©p b·∫°n n√≥i v·ªõi qu√° tr√¨nh d·ª´ng thay v√¨ c·ªë g·∫Øng ti·∫øp t·ª•c v·ªõi gi√° tr·ªã kh√¥ng h·ª£p l·ªá ho·∫∑c kh√¥ng ch√≠nh x√°c. Result enum s·ª≠ d·ª•ng h·ªá th·ªëng ki·ªÉu c·ªßa Rust ƒë·ªÉ ch·ªâ ra r·∫±ng c√°c ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông c√≥ th·ªÉ th·∫•t b·∫°i m·ªôt c√°ch m√† m√£ c·ªßa b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ kh√¥i ph·ª•c ƒë∆∞·ª£c. B·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng Result ƒë·ªÉ n√≥i v·ªõi m√£ g·ªçi m√£ c·ªßa b·∫°n r·∫±ng n√≥ c·∫ßn ph·∫£i x·ª≠ l√Ω th√†nh c√¥ng ho·∫∑c th·∫•t b·∫°i c√≥ th·ªÉ x·∫£y ra. S·ª≠ d·ª•ng panic! v√† Result trong c√°c t√¨nh hu·ªëng ph√π h·ª£p s·∫Ω l√†m m√£ c·ªßa b·∫°n ·ªïn ƒë·ªãnh h∆°n ƒë·ªëi v·ªõi c√°c v·∫•n ƒë·ªÅ kh√¥ng th·ªÉ tr√°nh ƒë∆∞·ª£c.

B√¢y gi·ªù b·∫°n ƒë√£ th·∫•y c√°c c√°ch s·ª≠ d·ª•ng h·ªØu √≠ch m√† th∆∞ vi·ªán chu·∫©n s·ª≠ d·ª•ng v·ªõi Option v√† Result enum, ch√∫ng ta s·∫Ω n√≥i v·ªÅ c√°ch ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông c·ªßa generics v√† c√°ch b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng ch√∫ng trong m√£ c·ªßa b·∫°n.

Generic Types, Traits, and Lifetimes

Every programming language has tools for effectively handling the duplication of concepts. In Rust, one such tool is generics: abstract stand-ins for concrete types or other properties. We can express the behavior of generics or how they relate to other generics without knowing what will be in their place when compiling and running the code.

Functions can take parameters of some generic type, instead of a concrete type like i32 or String, in the same way a function takes parameters with unknown values to run the same code on multiple concrete values. In fact, we‚Äôve already used generics in Chapter 6 with Option<T>, Chapter 8 with Vec<T> and HashMap<K, V>, and Chapter 9 with Result<T, E>. In this chapter, you‚Äôll explore how to define your own types, functions, and methods with generics!

First, we‚Äôll review how to extract a function to reduce code duplication. We‚Äôll then use the same technique to make a generic function from two functions that differ only in the types of their parameters. We‚Äôll also explain how to use generic types in struct and enum definitions.

Then you‚Äôll learn how to use traits to define behavior in a generic way. You can combine traits with generic types to constrain a generic type to accept only those types that have a particular behavior, as opposed to just any type.

Finally, we‚Äôll discuss lifetimes: a variety of generics that give the compiler information about how references relate to each other. Lifetimes allow us to give the compiler enough information about borrowed values so that it can ensure references will be valid in more situations than it could without our help.

Removing Duplication by Extracting a Function

Generics allow us to replace specific types with a placeholder that represents multiple types to remove code duplication. Before diving into generics syntax, then, let‚Äôs first look at how to remove duplication in a way that doesn‚Äôt involve generic types by extracting a function that replaces specific values with a placeholder that represents multiple values. Then we‚Äôll apply the same technique to extract a generic function! By looking at how to recognize duplicated code you can extract into a function, you‚Äôll start to recognize duplicated code that can use generics.

We begin with the short program in Listing 10-1 that finds the largest number in a list.

Filename: src/main.rs

fn main() {
    let number_list = vec![34, 50, 25, 100, 65];

    let mut largest = &number_list[0];

    for number in &number_list {
        if number > largest {
            largest = number;
        }
    }

    println!("The largest number is {}", largest);
    assert_eq!(*largest, 100);
}

Listing 10-1: Finding the largest number in a list of numbers

We store a list of integers in the variable number_list and place a reference to the first number in the list in a variable named largest. We then iterate through all the numbers in the list, and if the current number is greater than the number stored in largest, replace the reference in that variable. However, if the current number is less than or equal to the largest number seen so far, the variable doesn‚Äôt change, and the code moves on to the next number in the list. After considering all the numbers in the list, largest should refer to the largest number, which in this case is 100.

We've now been tasked with finding the largest number in two different lists of numbers. To do so, we can choose to duplicate the code in Listing 10-1 and use the same logic at two different places in the program, as shown in Listing 10-2.

Filename: src/main.rs

fn main() {
    let number_list = vec![34, 50, 25, 100, 65];

    let mut largest = &number_list[0];

    for number in &number_list {
        if number > largest {
            largest = number;
        }
    }

    println!("The largest number is {}", largest);

    let number_list = vec![102, 34, 6000, 89, 54, 2, 43, 8];

    let mut largest = &number_list[0];

    for number in &number_list {
        if number > largest {
            largest = number;
        }
    }

    println!("The largest number is {}", largest);
}

Listing 10-2: Code to find the largest number in two lists of numbers

Although this code works, duplicating code is tedious and error prone. We also have to remember to update the code in multiple places when we want to change it.

To eliminate this duplication, we‚Äôll create an abstraction by defining a function that operates on any list of integers passed in a parameter. This solution makes our code clearer and lets us express the concept of finding the largest number in a list abstractly.

In Listing 10-3, we extract the code that finds the largest number into a function named largest. Then we call the function to find the largest number in the two lists from Listing 10-2. We could also use the function on any other list of i32 values we might have in the future.

Filename: src/main.rs

fn largest(list: &[i32]) -> &i32 {
    let mut largest = &list[0];

    for item in list {
        if item > largest {
            largest = item;
        }
    }

    largest
}

fn main() {
    let number_list = vec![34, 50, 25, 100, 65];

    let result = largest(&number_list);
    println!("The largest number is {}", result);
    assert_eq!(*result, 100);

    let number_list = vec![102, 34, 6000, 89, 54, 2, 43, 8];

    let result = largest(&number_list);
    println!("The largest number is {}", result);
    assert_eq!(*result, 6000);
}

Listing 10-3: Abstracted code to find the largest number in two lists

The largest function has a parameter called list, which represents any concrete slice of i32 values we might pass into the function. As a result, when we call the function, the code runs on the specific values that we pass in.

In summary, here are the steps we took to change the code from Listing 10-2 to Listing 10-3:

  1. Identify duplicate code.
  2. Extract the duplicate code into the body of the function and specify the inputs and return values of that code in the function signature.
  3. Update the two instances of duplicated code to call the function instead.

Next, we‚Äôll use these same steps with generics to reduce code duplication. In the same way that the function body can operate on an abstract list instead of specific values, generics allow code to operate on abstract types.

For example, say we had two functions: one that finds the largest item in a slice of i32 values and one that finds the largest item in a slice of char values. How would we eliminate that duplication? Let‚Äôs find out!

Generic Data Types

We use generics to create definitions for items like function signatures or structs, which we can then use with many different concrete data types. Let‚Äôs first look at how to define functions, structs, enums, and methods using generics. Then we‚Äôll discuss how generics affect code performance.

In Function Definitions

When defining a function that uses generics, we place the generics in the signature of the function where we would usually specify the data types of the parameters and return value. Doing so makes our code more flexible and provides more functionality to callers of our function while preventing code duplication.

Continuing with our largest function, Listing 10-4 shows two functions that both find the largest value in a slice. We'll then combine these into a single function that uses generics.

Filename: src/main.rs

fn largest_i32(list: &[i32]) -> &i32 {
    let mut largest = &list[0];

    for item in list {
        if item > largest {
            largest = item;
        }
    }

    largest
}

fn largest_char(list: &[char]) -> &char {
    let mut largest = &list[0];

    for item in list {
        if item > largest {
            largest = item;
        }
    }

    largest
}

fn main() {
    let number_list = vec![34, 50, 25, 100, 65];

    let result = largest_i32(&number_list);
    println!("The largest number is {}", result);
    assert_eq!(*result, 100);

    let char_list = vec!['y', 'm', 'a', 'q'];

    let result = largest_char(&char_list);
    println!("The largest char is {}", result);
    assert_eq!(*result, 'y');
}

Listing 10-4: Two functions that differ only in their names and the types in their signatures

The largest_i32 function is the one we extracted in Listing 10-3 that finds the largest i32 in a slice. The largest_char function finds the largest char in a slice. The function bodies have the same code, so let‚Äôs eliminate the duplication by introducing a generic type parameter in a single function.

To parameterize the types in a new single function, we need to name the type parameter, just as we do for the value parameters to a function. You can use any identifier as a type parameter name. But we‚Äôll use T because, by convention, type parameter names in Rust are short, often just a letter, and Rust‚Äôs type-naming convention is CamelCase. Short for ‚Äútype,‚Äù T is the default choice of most Rust programmers.

When we use a parameter in the body of the function, we have to declare the parameter name in the signature so the compiler knows what that name means. Similarly, when we use a type parameter name in a function signature, we have to declare the type parameter name before we use it. To define the generic largest function, place type name declarations inside angle brackets, <>, between the name of the function and the parameter list, like this:

fn largest<T>(list: &[T]) -> &T {

We read this definition as: the function largest is generic over some type T. This function has one parameter named list, which is a slice of values of type T. The largest function will return a reference to a value of the same type T.

Listing 10-5 shows the combined largest function definition using the generic data type in its signature. The listing also shows how we can call the function with either a slice of i32 values or char values. Note that this code won‚Äôt compile yet, but we‚Äôll fix it later in this chapter.

Filename: src/main.rs

fn largest<T>(list: &[T]) -> &T {
    let mut largest = &list[0];

    for item in list {
        if item > largest {
            largest = item;
        }
    }

    largest
}

fn main() {
    let number_list = vec![34, 50, 25, 100, 65];

    let result = largest(&number_list);
    println!("The largest number is {}", result);

    let char_list = vec!['y', 'm', 'a', 'q'];

    let result = largest(&char_list);
    println!("The largest char is {}", result);
}

Listing 10-5: The largest function using generic type parameters; this doesn‚Äôt yet compile

If we compile this code right now, we‚Äôll get this error:

$ cargo run
   Compiling chapter10 v0.1.0 (file:///projects/chapter10)
error[E0369]: binary operation `>` cannot be applied to type `&T`
 --> src/main.rs:5:17
  |
5 |         if item > largest {
  |            ---- ^ ------- &T
  |            |
  |            &T
  |
help: consider restricting type parameter `T`
  |
1 | fn largest<T: std::cmp::PartialOrd>(list: &[T]) -> &T {
  |             ++++++++++++++++++++++

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0369`.
error: could not compile `chapter10` due to previous error

The help text mentions std::cmp::PartialOrd, which is a trait, and we‚Äôre going to talk about traits in the next section. For now, know that this error states that the body of largest won‚Äôt work for all possible types that T could be. Because we want to compare values of type T in the body, we can only use types whose values can be ordered. To enable comparisons, the standard library has the std::cmp::PartialOrd trait that you can implement on types (see Appendix C for more on this trait). By following the help text's suggestion, we restrict the types valid for T to only those that implement PartialOrd and this example will compile, because the standard library implements PartialOrd on both i32 and char.

In Struct Definitions

We can also define structs to use a generic type parameter in one or more fields using the <> syntax. Listing 10-6 defines a Point<T> struct to hold x and y coordinate values of any type.

Filename: src/main.rs

struct Point<T> {
    x: T,
    y: T,
}

fn main() {
    let integer = Point { x: 5, y: 10 };
    let float = Point { x: 1.0, y: 4.0 };
}

Listing 10-6: A Point<T> struct that holds x and y values of type T

The syntax for using generics in struct definitions is similar to that used in function definitions. First, we declare the name of the type parameter inside angle brackets just after the name of the struct. Then we use the generic type in the struct definition where we would otherwise specify concrete data types.

Note that because we‚Äôve used only one generic type to define Point<T>, this definition says that the Point<T> struct is generic over some type T, and the fields x and y are both that same type, whatever that type may be. If we create an instance of a Point<T> that has values of different types, as in Listing 10-7, our code won‚Äôt compile.

Filename: src/main.rs

struct Point<T> {
    x: T,
    y: T,
}

fn main() {
    let wont_work = Point { x: 5, y: 4.0 };
}

Listing 10-7: The fields x and y must be the same type because both have the same generic data type T.

In this example, when we assign the integer value 5 to x, we let the compiler know that the generic type T will be an integer for this instance of Point<T>. Then when we specify 4.0 for y, which we‚Äôve defined to have the same type as x, we‚Äôll get a type mismatch error like this:

$ cargo run
   Compiling chapter10 v0.1.0 (file:///projects/chapter10)
error[E0308]: mismatched types
 --> src/main.rs:7:38
  |
7 |     let wont_work = Point { x: 5, y: 4.0 };
  |                                      ^^^ expected integer, found floating-point number

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0308`.
error: could not compile `chapter10` due to previous error

To define a Point struct where x and y are both generics but could have different types, we can use multiple generic type parameters. For example, in Listing 10-8, we change the definition of Point to be generic over types T and U where x is of type T and y is of type U.

Filename: src/main.rs

struct Point<T, U> {
    x: T,
    y: U,
}

fn main() {
    let both_integer = Point { x: 5, y: 10 };
    let both_float = Point { x: 1.0, y: 4.0 };
    let integer_and_float = Point { x: 5, y: 4.0 };
}

Listing 10-8: A Point<T, U> generic over two types so that x and y can be values of different types

Now all the instances of Point shown are allowed! You can use as many generic type parameters in a definition as you want, but using more than a few makes your code hard to read. If you're finding you need lots of generic types in your code, it could indicate that your code needs restructuring into smaller pieces.

In Enum Definitions

As we did with structs, we can define enums to hold generic data types in their variants. Let‚Äôs take another look at the Option<T> enum that the standard library provides, which we used in Chapter 6:

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
enum Option<T> {
    Some(T),
    None,
}
}

This definition should now make more sense to you. As you can see, the Option<T> enum is generic over type T and has two variants: Some, which holds one value of type T, and a None variant that doesn‚Äôt hold any value. By using the Option<T> enum, we can express the abstract concept of an optional value, and because Option<T> is generic, we can use this abstraction no matter what the type of the optional value is.

Enums can use multiple generic types as well. The definition of the Result enum that we used in Chapter 9 is one example:

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
enum Result<T, E> {
    Ok(T),
    Err(E),
}
}

The Result enum is generic over two types, T and E, and has two variants: Ok, which holds a value of type T, and Err, which holds a value of type E. This definition makes it convenient to use the Result enum anywhere we have an operation that might succeed (return a value of some type T) or fail (return an error of some type E). In fact, this is what we used to open a file in Listing 9-3, where T was filled in with the type std::fs::File when the file was opened successfully and E was filled in with the type std::io::Error when there were problems opening the file.

When you recognize situations in your code with multiple struct or enum definitions that differ only in the types of the values they hold, you can avoid duplication by using generic types instead.

In Method Definitions

We can implement methods on structs and enums (as we did in Chapter 5) and use generic types in their definitions, too. Listing 10-9 shows the Point<T> struct we defined in Listing 10-6 with a method named x implemented on it.

Filename: src/main.rs

struct Point<T> {
    x: T,
    y: T,
}

impl<T> Point<T> {
    fn x(&self) -> &T {
        &self.x
    }
}

fn main() {
    let p = Point { x: 5, y: 10 };

    println!("p.x = {}", p.x());
}

Listing 10-9: Implementing a method named x on the Point<T> struct that will return a reference to the x field of type T

Here, we‚Äôve defined a method named x on Point<T> that returns a reference to the data in the field x.

Note that we have to declare T just after impl so we can use T to specify that we‚Äôre implementing methods on the type Point<T>. By declaring T as a generic type after impl, Rust can identify that the type in the angle brackets in Point is a generic type rather than a concrete type. We could have chosen a different name for this generic parameter than the generic parameter declared in the struct definition, but using the same name is conventional. Methods written within an impl that declares the generic type will be defined on any instance of the type, no matter what concrete type ends up substituting for the generic type.

We can also specify constraints on generic types when defining methods on the type. We could, for example, implement methods only on Point<f32> instances rather than on Point<T> instances with any generic type. In Listing 10-10 we use the concrete type f32, meaning we don‚Äôt declare any types after impl.

Filename: src/main.rs

struct Point<T> {
    x: T,
    y: T,
}

impl<T> Point<T> {
    fn x(&self) -> &T {
        &self.x
    }
}

impl Point<f32> {
    fn distance_from_origin(&self) -> f32 {
        (self.x.powi(2) + self.y.powi(2)).sqrt()
    }
}

fn main() {
    let p = Point { x: 5, y: 10 };

    println!("p.x = {}", p.x());
}

Listing 10-10: An impl block that only applies to a struct with a particular concrete type for the generic type parameter T

This code means the type Point<f32> will have a distance_from_origin method; other instances of Point<T> where T is not of type f32 will not have this method defined. The method measures how far our point is from the point at coordinates (0.0, 0.0) and uses mathematical operations that are available only for floating point types.

Generic type parameters in a struct definition aren‚Äôt always the same as those you use in that same struct‚Äôs method signatures. Listing 10-11 uses the generic types X1 and Y1 for the Point struct and X2 Y2 for the mixup method signature to make the example clearer. The method creates a new Point instance with the x value from the self Point (of type X1) and the y value from the passed-in Point (of type Y2).

Filename: src/main.rs

struct Point<X1, Y1> {
    x: X1,
    y: Y1,
}

impl<X1, Y1> Point<X1, Y1> {
    fn mixup<X2, Y2>(self, other: Point<X2, Y2>) -> Point<X1, Y2> {
        Point {
            x: self.x,
            y: other.y,
        }
    }
}

fn main() {
    let p1 = Point { x: 5, y: 10.4 };
    let p2 = Point { x: "Hello", y: 'c' };

    let p3 = p1.mixup(p2);

    println!("p3.x = {}, p3.y = {}", p3.x, p3.y);
}

Listing 10-11: A method that uses generic types different from its struct‚Äôs definition

In main, we‚Äôve defined a Point that has an i32 for x (with value 5) and an f64 for y (with value 10.4). The p2 variable is a Point struct that has a string slice for x (with value "Hello") and a char for y (with value c). Calling mixup on p1 with the argument p2 gives us p3, which will have an i32 for x, because x came from p1. The p3 variable will have a char for y, because y came from p2. The println! macro call will print p3.x = 5, p3.y = c.

The purpose of this example is to demonstrate a situation in which some generic parameters are declared with impl and some are declared with the method definition. Here, the generic parameters X1 and Y1 are declared after impl because they go with the struct definition. The generic parameters X2 and Y2 are declared after fn mixup, because they‚Äôre only relevant to the method.

Performance of Code Using Generics

You might be wondering whether there is a runtime cost when using generic type parameters. The good news is that using generic types won't make your program run any slower than it would with concrete types.

Rust accomplishes this by performing monomorphization of the code using generics at compile time. Monomorphization is the process of turning generic code into specific code by filling in the concrete types that are used when compiled. In this process, the compiler does the opposite of the steps we used to create the generic function in Listing 10-5: the compiler looks at all the places where generic code is called and generates code for the concrete types the generic code is called with.

Let‚Äôs look at how this works by using the standard library‚Äôs generic Option<T> enum:

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
let integer = Some(5);
let float = Some(5.0);
}

When Rust compiles this code, it performs monomorphization. During that process, the compiler reads the values that have been used in Option<T> instances and identifies two kinds of Option<T>: one is i32 and the other is f64. As such, it expands the generic definition of Option<T> into two definitions specialized to i32 and f64, thereby replacing the generic definition with the specific ones.

The monomorphized version of the code looks similar to the following (the compiler uses different names than what we‚Äôre using here for illustration):

Filename: src/main.rs

enum Option_i32 {
    Some(i32),
    None,
}

enum Option_f64 {
    Some(f64),
    None,
}

fn main() {
    let integer = Option_i32::Some(5);
    let float = Option_f64::Some(5.0);
}

The generic Option<T> is replaced with the specific definitions created by the compiler. Because Rust compiles generic code into code that specifies the type in each instance, we pay no runtime cost for using generics. When the code runs, it performs just as it would if we had duplicated each definition by hand. The process of monomorphization makes Rust‚Äôs generics extremely efficient at runtime.

Traits: Defining Shared Behavior

A trait defines functionality a particular type has and can share with other types. We can use traits to define shared behavior in an abstract way. We can use trait bounds to specify that a generic type can be any type that has certain behavior.

Note: Traits are similar to a feature often called interfaces in other languages, although with some differences.

Defining a Trait

A type‚Äôs behavior consists of the methods we can call on that type. Different types share the same behavior if we can call the same methods on all of those types. Trait definitions are a way to group method signatures together to define a set of behaviors necessary to accomplish some purpose.

For example, let‚Äôs say we have multiple structs that hold various kinds and amounts of text: a NewsArticle struct that holds a news story filed in a particular location and a Tweet that can have at most 280 characters along with metadata that indicates whether it was a new tweet, a retweet, or a reply to another tweet.

We want to make a media aggregator library crate named aggregator that can display summaries of data that might be stored in a NewsArticle or Tweet instance. To do this, we need a summary from each type, and we‚Äôll request that summary by calling a summarize method on an instance. Listing 10-12 shows the definition of a public Summary trait that expresses this behavior.

Filename: src/lib.rs

pub trait Summary {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String;
}

Listing 10-12: A Summary trait that consists of the behavior provided by a summarize method

Here, we declare a trait using the trait keyword and then the trait‚Äôs name, which is Summary in this case. We‚Äôve also declared the trait as pub so that crates depending on this crate can make use of this trait too, as we‚Äôll see in a few examples. Inside the curly brackets, we declare the method signatures that describe the behaviors of the types that implement this trait, which in this case is fn summarize(&self) -> String.

After the method signature, instead of providing an implementation within curly brackets, we use a semicolon. Each type implementing this trait must provide its own custom behavior for the body of the method. The compiler will enforce that any type that has the Summary trait will have the method summarize defined with this signature exactly.

A trait can have multiple methods in its body: the method signatures are listed one per line and each line ends in a semicolon.

Implementing a Trait on a Type

Now that we‚Äôve defined the desired signatures of the Summary trait‚Äôs methods, we can implement it on the types in our media aggregator. Listing 10-13 shows an implementation of the Summary trait on the NewsArticle struct that uses the headline, the author, and the location to create the return value of summarize. For the Tweet struct, we define summarize as the username followed by the entire text of the tweet, assuming that tweet content is already limited to 280 characters.

Filename: src/lib.rs

pub trait Summary {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String;
}

pub struct NewsArticle {
    pub headline: String,
    pub location: String,
    pub author: String,
    pub content: String,
}

impl Summary for NewsArticle {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("{}, by {} ({})", self.headline, self.author, self.location)
    }
}

pub struct Tweet {
    pub username: String,
    pub content: String,
    pub reply: bool,
    pub retweet: bool,
}

impl Summary for Tweet {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("{}: {}", self.username, self.content)
    }
}

Listing 10-13: Implementing the Summary trait on the NewsArticle and Tweet types

Implementing a trait on a type is similar to implementing regular methods. The difference is that after impl, we put the trait name we want to implement, then use the for keyword, and then specify the name of the type we want to implement the trait for. Within the impl block, we put the method signatures that the trait definition has defined. Instead of adding a semicolon after each signature, we use curly brackets and fill in the method body with the specific behavior that we want the methods of the trait to have for the particular type.

Now that the library has implemented the Summary trait on NewsArticle and Tweet, users of the crate can call the trait methods on instances of NewsArticle and Tweet in the same way we call regular methods. The only difference is that the user must bring the trait into scope as well as the types. Here‚Äôs an example of how a binary crate could use our aggregator library crate:

use aggregator::{Summary, Tweet};

fn main() {
    let tweet = Tweet {
        username: String::from("horse_ebooks"),
        content: String::from(
            "of course, as you probably already know, people",
        ),
        reply: false,
        retweet: false,
    };

    println!("1 new tweet: {}", tweet.summarize());
}

This code prints 1 new tweet: horse_ebooks: of course, as you probably already know, people.

Other crates that depend on the aggregator crate can also bring the Summary trait into scope to implement Summary on their own types. One restriction to note is that we can implement a trait on a type only if at least one of the trait or the type is local to our crate. For example, we can implement standard library traits like Display on a custom type like Tweet as part of our aggregator crate functionality, because the type Tweet is local to our aggregator crate. We can also implement Summary on Vec<T> in our aggregator crate, because the trait Summary is local to our aggregator crate.

But we can‚Äôt implement external traits on external types. For example, we can‚Äôt implement the Display trait on Vec<T> within our aggregator crate, because Display and Vec<T> are both defined in the standard library and aren‚Äôt local to our aggregator crate. This restriction is part of a property called coherence, and more specifically the orphan rule, so named because the parent type is not present. This rule ensures that other people‚Äôs code can‚Äôt break your code and vice versa. Without the rule, two crates could implement the same trait for the same type, and Rust wouldn‚Äôt know which implementation to use.

Default Implementations

Sometimes it‚Äôs useful to have default behavior for some or all of the methods in a trait instead of requiring implementations for all methods on every type. Then, as we implement the trait on a particular type, we can keep or override each method‚Äôs default behavior.

In Listing 10-14 we specify a default string for the summarize method of the Summary trait instead of only defining the method signature, as we did in Listing 10-12.

Filename: src/lib.rs

pub trait Summary {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        String::from("(Read more...)")
    }
}

pub struct NewsArticle {
    pub headline: String,
    pub location: String,
    pub author: String,
    pub content: String,
}

impl Summary for NewsArticle {}

pub struct Tweet {
    pub username: String,
    pub content: String,
    pub reply: bool,
    pub retweet: bool,
}

impl Summary for Tweet {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("{}: {}", self.username, self.content)
    }
}
